headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, could you talk about the -- well, I guess, could you talk about the ongoing transition from swaps to futures in the rate complex? Maybe where you're seeing evidence of progress and from here, maybe drivers and catalysts. And included in the respons
componenttext: First, could you talk about the -- well, I guess, could you talk about the ongoing transition from swaps to futures in the rate complex? Maybe where you're seeing evidence of progress and from here, maybe drivers and catalysts. And included in the response, can you talk about portfolio margining? I know Gill mentioned that conversations are still taking place. But are you getting uptake on the portfolio margining side? And is that a catalyst? And then also, the slide on OTC clearing revenue, that seems to continue as well. So swaps to futures.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Sean Tully jumping in. Thanks for the question. It's been very exciting over the last few years in terms of -- what we've seen in terms of clients transitioning from swaps over to futures. If you recall early last year, Greenwich Associates publis
componenttext: This is Sean Tully jumping in. Thanks for the question. It's been very exciting over the last few years in terms of -- what we've seen in terms of clients transitioning from swaps over to futures. If you recall early last year, Greenwich Associates published a study looking at our interest rate futures on total cost analysis basis relative to the swaps marketplace. And saw that our treasury futures, our Eurodollar futures, our Deliverable Swap Futures, on a consistent basis, offer you the same risk profile or similar risk profile to its trade swaps at a far lower cost. So it seems since 2012 when the mandate clearance rate swaps got kicked in, a big increase, for example, in our penetration of the cash treasury bond market. So treasury futures back in 2012 traded 66% of the average daily volume of the cash driven bond market. Last year, if you look at it, we were at 75%. So very significant increase in terms of our market share relative to the rest of the marketplace. In fact, last year, because of the jump in the gap, right, relative to bond future, if you adjust for that duration jump, that were -- our equivalent penetration now of the cash treasury market is about 78%. So we continue to see progress. We continue to see migration into our trade marketplace. If you look actually this morning we're at over 62 million open interest in our interest rate futures complex -- interest rate futures and options, a near record. So I'm very excited from that standpoint. On the interest swap side, continued innovation in that marketplace. There were challenges last year relative to the CME basis relative to LCH, but continued innovation is allowing us to continue to get traction. So last year, we had -- saw huge growth in our Mexican peso interest rate swap clearing, and we are now clearing approximately half of that marketplace. And then in December, we had our first trades in Brazilian real cleared interest swaps. If you get the Mexican peso, since we are unique in offering that relative to the global marketplace, we are now clearing about half of the global Mexican peso interest rate swap market, and it's our third mostly important currency. Other exciting developments we're seeing is the TN [ph] future. So relative to the increases in regulation, the increases in costs, relative to capital requirements, on banks in particular, a key end future, very exciting new launch where we're seeing a migration into an exciting new product. So the TN futures, the single most successful, actually launched after the first few mix in history relative to ADV open interest and a number of large open interest holders. So already after 3 weeks, we're seeing 58,000 open interest this morning. We're seeing around 25,000 ADV recently and over 140 participants -- so very, very exciting. Now the increases that we're seeing, in particular, coming from asset managers hedge funds and corporates. Asset managers, last year, actually, outperformed to the rest of our market segments by about 9% in terms of their growth in our interest rate complex. So we see a continued migration. And we're continuing to innovate on the swaps area. So with the Mexican peso and with the BRL, today we offer 19 currencies relative to our competition's 17 currencies. In addition to that, we do look to launch swaps options clearing, earlier this year, as another unique value proposition to marketplace offering unique credit and capital management tools.

componenttextpreview: Ken, let me just add something really quick here. We went down a couple million dollars in revenue swaps clearing. But as you recall, a couple of years ago, several years ago, as we started to introduce clearing of swaps, there were a lot of people that t
componenttext: Ken, let me just add something really quick here. We went down a couple million dollars in revenue swaps clearing. But as you recall, a couple of years ago, several years ago, as we started to introduce clearing of swaps, there were a lot of people that thought we would make anywhere between $500 million and $1 billion doing this business. We went out for very aggressively to price this in order to build up our core business and to grow revenues in our core business. And I think what Bill and Sean just walked you through is a couple of million dollars down in swaps clearing, but multiples of that in our core business. So I think that strategy really worked to perfection.

componenttext: This is Sameer Murukutla calling in for Michael Carrier. Just on the expense guidance, the growth of 1% is pretty conservative relative to your peers. Can you give us some details on what your top line outlook is, given the 1% growth?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you know, we don't give out guidance on volume, which is the main driver relative to clearing transaction fees. But as we look at it as a management team, we're focused really on two things: managing our expenditures and growing our top line; and expan
componenttext: As you know, we don't give out guidance on volume, which is the main driver relative to clearing transaction fees. But as we look at it as a management team, we're focused really on two things: managing our expenditures and growing our top line; and expanding our margins. So you're right, we were expecting a very modest 1% increase in expenses. And I think what we're looking at is 2 drivers. One being our market data revenue, which we showed was -- where we showed the increase about 4% to 5%, and then we've also used the lever in terms of pricing in our transaction fees. So we provided a tremendous amount of value to our clients, so we have a 2% increase in -- across-the-board in our transaction fees. So when you take a look at the month of January, we've had a record volume for the month of January. We've seen large increases in our options complex. So the things that we laid out to do, growing internationally, growing our options complex, and we've taken the opportunity to adjust prices. So our top line is -- we're hitting on all levers there. And on the expense side, just one of the things that we're doing, like I said, is managing the expenditures very carefully. And we've really focused on efficiency in light of security spending, regulatory spending, which we've made investments in over time. And we continue to look at our infra -- our technological infrastructure. Also we are looking at keeping our conversation [ph] relatively flat as well as we kind of manage the human capital here, too.

componenttextpreview: My question is on clearing houses, since I got one question. And -- so just today, there was a journal article about the tests -- stress testing clearinghouses in Europe. Kim and [indiscernible] just talked about testing recovery resilience here. So I gue
componenttext: My question is on clearing houses, since I got one question. And -- so just today, there was a journal article about the tests -- stress testing clearinghouses in Europe. Kim and [indiscernible] just talked about testing recovery resilience here. So I guess, the question is, first, is there anything -- do you have a view on what could be coming down the road, will there be any incremental costs or capital needed in the clearing house in your view? And then the second part of it is, EUREX also got approved as a clearing house here in the U.S. You're over there in London or in Europe, do you have any plans to expand the clearing beyond, I guess, the FX -- I believe it's metal that you clear right now?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Richard, it's Kim. With respect to the stress testing issue for clearinghouses, we invest significant effort already in various types of stress testing in the clearing house that we perform on a daily basis, including stress testing of the risk waterfall
componenttext: Richard, it's Kim. With respect to the stress testing issue for clearinghouses, we invest significant effort already in various types of stress testing in the clearing house that we perform on a daily basis, including stress testing of the risk waterfall and the capital that's needed for CME to contribute to that. So we would not anticipate any impact from minor changes in regulation there.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: With respect to the CME exchange in Europe, now our plan is to expand beyond the agricultural products and the FX products that are there. And I'll ask Derek to make a comment there.
componenttext: With respect to the CME exchange in Europe, now our plan is to expand beyond the agricultural products and the FX products that are there. And I'll ask Derek to make a comment there.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, we've actually been quite successful in building the European utilities business out there. So if you look at the -- we actually just set a recent open interest record of about 58,000 contracts of which about 55,000 is in our European utilit
componenttext: Yes. I think, we've actually been quite successful in building the European utilities business out there. So if you look at the -- we actually just set a recent open interest record of about 58,000 contracts of which about 55,000 is in our European utilities slate of power gas and emission. So we're very excited we had a new ADV record in cocoa, which is also clearing -- traded on the European exchange, clearing through the European clearing house. So we like the open interest build and the ADV. It's really accessing a brand-new client base for us that extends us into the footprints of users that are not traditional users of Henry Hub or [indiscernible] or products that are part of our core record-setting franchise this year. So good expansion. Looking for more growth in 2016.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question for you on the energy business. How do you expect the lift of the U.S. oil export, I guess, to impact the business, I guess, Gill, I heard you talk a little bit in the prepared remarks that you guys are excited about the opportunity. But maybe
componenttext: A question for you on the energy business. How do you expect the lift of the U.S. oil export, I guess, to impact the business, I guess, Gill, I heard you talk a little bit in the prepared remarks that you guys are excited about the opportunity. But maybe provide more granularity, either into specific contracts, strategies, or new users you potentially could target given this change.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, its Derek, I'll jump in here. Actually, we've hardly seen a pretty significant increase in participation in the levels of activity across our entire suite of products. There was actually an article out this morning on Bloomberg talking about a produc
componenttext: Yes, its Derek, I'll jump in here. Actually, we've hardly seen a pretty significant increase in participation in the levels of activity across our entire suite of products. There was actually an article out this morning on Bloomberg talking about a product that we just launched 9 months ago, the Look Storage [ph] contract, that reflects exactly the infrastructure shifts and the market dynamic shifts that are now reflective of a waterborne [ph] WTI products. So we've got the participation levels, we -- not only did we hit large open interest holder record levels in 2015, we actually saw record levels of Chinese participation and revenue generation. In fact, the greatest revenue generator for us in China in 2015 was our energies complex. About 82% growth year-on-year there. So this is a product that the story is one of a globalizing waterborne product. The market now, I think the first shift had actually left the Gulf Coast last week and headed for Japan. So this is something we've been positioning for over the last 18 months or so. We put ourselves in a position, with both the innovative new storage contract with Luke launched about 9 months ago, in addition to our globalizing sales efforts to make sure that wherever there is an interest in energies, we're going to make sure that we are pounding the pavement with our customers. And then finally on Page 12 of the deck that we circulated, you'll actually notice the 22% of our energies revenue now come from outside the U.S. That's up from just 18% last year, 2 years ago. So we're seeing significant growth in the participation in January, particularly as a continuation of that trend. So we're globalizing our footprint, we're expanding our customer base and there's -- and that gas piece, I'm happy to go in to as well. But I think I've got my time used up on this one.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Ken Hill of Barclays.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Ken Hill of Barclays.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to ask, you guys have a number of investment companies that are pretty interesting as far as portfolio companies you have on the technology side. One of this is the [indiscernible], which tends to get the most attention in the digital payment
componenttext: So I wanted to ask, you guys have a number of investment companies that are pretty interesting as far as portfolio companies you have on the technology side. One of this is the [indiscernible], which tends to get the most attention in the digital payment area. I was wondering if you could talk about the investments you're making in clearing payment infrastructure. And then how you actually see that evolving? I'm assuming that had a lot of implications for your customers and for you as well on the expense side. So when do you think some of these kind of newer companies might bring that technology to market to impact you both in a meaningful way?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ken, this is John. We do have a venture group, CME ventures, that has been investing in technology companies that we see as potentially being important to us in the long run. So we've been investing in realtime payments, we've been investing in bloc
componenttext: Sure, Ken, this is John. We do have a venture group, CME ventures, that has been investing in technology companies that we see as potentially being important to us in the long run. So we've been investing in realtime payments, we've been investing in block chain, we've been investing in big data, computing technology companies and the like. So it's important for us because what we're able to do is by making these investments, we can get a -- kind of a view of kind of the future, if you will, and bring that kind of that innovation back into the company. And one of the things that we have a strong culture on is innovation and bringing this knowledge into the company helps us in terms of our long-term planning.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just to add to what John said. If you look at some of the emerging technologies and investments that we have made, they translate very neatly into use cases for us. And so -- there are bunch of folks running a bunch of use cases across, not just the
componenttext: Yes. Just to add to what John said. If you look at some of the emerging technologies and investments that we have made, they translate very neatly into use cases for us. And so -- there are bunch of folks running a bunch of use cases across, not just the payment and settlement side, but across many aspects of the operations of the firm, with the intention to reduce not just our cost but the cost of connecting into our client base. And in turn, reducing our client's cost.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Brian Bedell of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to Brian Bedell of Deutsche Bank.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just on the international theme. John, you talked about what type of RPC trends you're seeing from the non-U.S. users versus the U.S. So if you are penetrating that market faster, especially on the energy side increasingly there and also on the rate
componenttext: Maybe just on the international theme. John, you talked about what type of RPC trends you're seeing from the non-U.S. users versus the U.S. So if you are penetrating that market faster, especially on the energy side increasingly there and also on the rate side. If you have had something that can drive material lift to the RPC over and above your forecast. And then, also, just comment on the program to incentivize users on brand [ph], where we stand on that right now?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. When you take a look at the RPC from outside the U.S., it tends to be higher than within the U.S. because those clients tend not to be members of the exchange, they pay a higher rate. So outside the U.S., it's about 37% higher RPC than within the U.
componenttext: Sure. When you take a look at the RPC from outside the U.S., it tends to be higher than within the U.S. because those clients tend not to be members of the exchange, they pay a higher rate. So outside the U.S., it's about 37% higher RPC than within the U.S., which -- and also when you heard Derek penetrating outside the U.S. in the energy space, energy tends to be one of our higher RPC product. So it's really -- it's an important growth area for us, both from a rate per contract, but also from a volume perspective. I'll turn it over to Bryan to comment on the clients overseas.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think this demonstrates our very targeted campaign approach to selling, and it's delivering results across all of our asset classes. We've seen an 81% increase in activity out of the energy complex, the main drivers have been from Asia and some of
componenttext: Yes, I think this demonstrates our very targeted campaign approach to selling, and it's delivering results across all of our asset classes. We've seen an 81% increase in activity out of the energy complex, the main drivers have been from Asia and some of the emerging EMEA markets and in particularly, we've seen some nice new business coming from new commercial clients. We've generated about, I think, 88 or close to 90-something commercial clients globally, and 1/3 of that's coming out of international. So you're going to see more and more efforts in that regard, in terms of our targeted approach to these clients. We've been also very heavily intensifying our efforts in our cross-selling. You've heard me talk about that in the past, and we've generated new business from new firms. As a result, I think about 500 new firms, and that's broken down to 121 asset managers, 88 new commercial clients and about 300-plus hedge funds. Again, 1/3 of that is coming out of international.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say Brent to jumping in specifically on the energy side, with Brent particular, we actually rolled back some of the incentives in January. So that's going to help RPC a little bit. We're continuing to grow the business, about 140,000 ADVs, maintaining
componenttext: I'd say Brent to jumping in specifically on the energy side, with Brent particular, we actually rolled back some of the incentives in January. So that's going to help RPC a little bit. We're continuing to grow the business, about 140,000 ADVs, maintaining about 12% market share and most pleasingly, we're actually seeing an increased market share of the Brent TI spread that are traded as a listed spread. We're up to about 40% of that market and on bigger days, we're closer to 50%. So RPC helped, and we're getting into more diversified client base by adding more Brent participation on the commercial side.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Kyle Voigt of KBW.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Kyle Voigt of KBW.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple for John on the market data guidance. I guess, we had expected a bit of a larger uptick in revenues given the full elimination of the fee waiver this year. Can you help us understand what your assumptions are for subscriber attrition for 201
componenttext: Just a couple for John on the market data guidance. I guess, we had expected a bit of a larger uptick in revenues given the full elimination of the fee waiver this year. Can you help us understand what your assumptions are for subscriber attrition for 2016 as you moved to 100% of the full monthly rate? And then do you already have insight into customer attrition at this point in the year? And then, I guess, lastly, just can you just remind us when was the last time you adjusted monthly prices for the market data terminals and how often you typically review this pricing?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Kyle. As I indicated in the prepared remarks, we're expecting a 4% to 5% increase in terms of overall market data revenue. As you know, we're moving -- we've moved our -- grandfathered, fee waived clients from 0 to $42.50 and now up to $85.
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Kyle. As I indicated in the prepared remarks, we're expecting a 4% to 5% increase in terms of overall market data revenue. As you know, we're moving -- we've moved our -- grandfathered, fee waived clients from 0 to $42.50 and now up to $85. The same as our other customers. With respect to attrition and the like, we don't have that information now as we're going through the first billing cycle for customers at the $85 level. So our base core previously, the non-grandfathered clients have remained relatively stable. The grandfathered ones, I think we'll have a little bit more insight as we go into billing at the full rate. Bryan, would you like to comment on it from what you see from a customer perspective?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just feel that we've been a very good job in terms of stabilizing any reduction in the terminals, and you can see that over the course of the past 1.5 years since we put in the elimination of this waiver. We've seen consistent activity and I would say s
componenttext: I just feel that we've been a very good job in terms of stabilizing any reduction in the terminals, and you can see that over the course of the past 1.5 years since we put in the elimination of this waiver. We've seen consistent activity and I would say some additional takeup from those at the full rate and in terms of those that were grandfathered. We've also seen consistent usage from that group, and we're monitoring it closely, as John indicated, but we're pretty confident that we went through the main consolidation since we eliminated that fee waiver. And we're really focused now on delivering new products and augmenting the data business that we have today.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: And then, sorry, on the -- also on the monthly, how often you typically adjust the monthly prices for market data terminals and how often you review that pricing or when was the last time you reviewed that?

componenttext: Sorry, Kyle, this is John. We generally have increased prices every 2 years. And the last time we did it was 2 years ago.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Patrick O'Shaughnessy of Raymond James.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it seems like the clearinghouse equivalents rule is kind of coming to ahead. I think February 21 is the near [ph] deadline in terms of determining whether U.S. clearinghouses are compliant for European banks. What do you see as the resolution of this i
componenttext: So it seems like the clearinghouse equivalents rule is kind of coming to ahead. I think February 21 is the near [ph] deadline in terms of determining whether U.S. clearinghouses are compliant for European banks. What do you see as the resolution of this issue?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Pat, I'm going to ask the Chairman to chime in.
componenttext: Hey, Pat, I'm going to ask the Chairman to chime in.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pat, this is Terry, thanks, Gill. Pat, we've been working on the equivalents issue for quite some time now, and we've been working with Chairman, Tim Massad, actually since the day he has been sworn in into the administration to take the role at the CFTC.
componenttext: Pat, this is Terry, thanks, Gill. Pat, we've been working on the equivalents issue for quite some time now, and we've been working with Chairman, Tim Massad, actually since the day he has been sworn in into the administration to take the role at the CFTC. This has been a big issue. This has been a long road working through all the different issues. We feel very confident that we've gotten all the issues resolved. I met with the Chairman, along with Gill and Kim and a few other folks just a couple of days ago. And I assure you that Chairman Massad understands the magnitude of the potential market disruption if in fact, the United States -- the U.S. is not deemed equivalent prior to the February 21 frontloading date. So that being said, it gives us some comfort but we would like to see it ahead of time. That being said, we've seen some recent articles I think in Risk magazine, where a couple of banks have made comments as to what they may or may not do come February 21. And then you've heard from some other participants saying that they feel very confident and they're not overly concerned about this. This is an issue that we're very focused on, and we will stay focused on until it's granted. But again, I think the Chairman has recognized that there could be market disruptions and that would be the worst thing that could happen to, not only to the U.S. market, but to the European participation -- participants as well, if the equivalents is not granted to the United States. So we feel confident that we will get this done.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Chris Harris of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The S&P Dow Jones venture had a very strong year. I'm wondering if you can expand a little bit on what the drivers of that were. Was it just volume, strong volumes or is something else going on there? And then anything you guys can share about the outlook
componenttext: The S&P Dow Jones venture had a very strong year. I'm wondering if you can expand a little bit on what the drivers of that were. Was it just volume, strong volumes or is something else going on there? And then anything you guys can share about the outlook would be helpful, too.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, this is John. In terms of the JV, we're very pleased with our investment in our joint venture with McGraw-Hill. The general drivers for the business are assets under management as well as license fee generated from exchanges that utilize their trade
componenttext: Sure, this is John. In terms of the JV, we're very pleased with our investment in our joint venture with McGraw-Hill. The general drivers for the business are assets under management as well as license fee generated from exchanges that utilize their trademark and IP. So it would be primarily CME and the CBOE. And that -- so we end up profiting from activity, both from the move from active to passive investing, which is a mega trend in the investing space as well as trading activity, on  both from futures and options as well. So we think we were very bullish on that business. It has characteristics very similar to ours, a lot of leverage in their model and I think we're very optimistic in terms of the trends in investing and the position that the JV has globally.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Rob Rutschow of CLSA Americas.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: You gave some very helpful commentary on the non-U.S., I had a couple small follow-ups. You have a lot of new clients, but are those the ones that are driving additional non-U.S. volume? Or you think better penetration from older non-U.S. clients and thos
componenttext: You gave some very helpful commentary on the non-U.S., I had a couple small follow-ups. You have a lot of new clients, but are those the ones that are driving additional non-U.S. volume? Or you think better penetration from older non-U.S. clients and those new clients are kind of pipelined for additional growth? And then secondly, are you seeing -- are you taking some share from some of the non-U.S. venues that have look-alike contract, especially for some of your commodity products?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is Bryan, I'm going to break it down into 3 categories. One of the benefits of having the broad swap of interest rate products that we represent, we're able to reach the client base particularly within London. We brought in some new business, part
componenttext: So this is Bryan, I'm going to break it down into 3 categories. One of the benefits of having the broad swap of interest rate products that we represent, we're able to reach the client base particularly within London. We brought in some new business, particularly in the shorter end of our yield curve that we just hadn't tapped before, and that's a strong testament to the product complex that we represent. Also, I think I alluded to earlier, our intensified efforts on cross-selling. So from existing clients, what that means is, going in, working with them through strong rigorous marketing and education programs and helping existing users understand how we can complement their business, for example with metals, having them come in and do some activity into our foreign currency products to hedge their foreign currency risk. That has been very successful. So to be able to back that up, new business from existing customers, we've seen existing customers now trading over, I think, it's 1,700 new products that they hadn't tried before. So it's new business from existing customers and then it's also new business from new customers, which I outlined earlier. Again, it's a combination of targeted sales, bringing together our marketing, our strategy and our business line units together to go out there and call that new business.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Jonathan [indiscernible] of [indiscernible].

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: The earnings trajectory of the exchange is going way up. Stock multiples are coming down a little bit though. So I'm surmising that there's some fears about the trading community. So I'm just curious if you can talk about the breadth of the user base. In
componenttext: The earnings trajectory of the exchange is going way up. Stock multiples are coming down a little bit though. So I'm surmising that there's some fears about the trading community. So I'm just curious if you can talk about the breadth of the user base. In 2011, you had a big step up in activity only to be met with declines in 2012 and 2013. So curious, are there any signs or may be different this time that the activity levels are more sustainable just from a breadth standpoint going forward?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Bryan, again. I mean, if you look across the client segments, we actually, for the past year year-on-year, saw anywhere from single-digit, and I would say single-digit from the proprietary segment to double-digit growth, double-digit covering our
componenttext: This is Bryan, again. I mean, if you look across the client segments, we actually, for the past year year-on-year, saw anywhere from single-digit, and I would say single-digit from the proprietary segment to double-digit growth, double-digit covering our hedge fund asset management community as well as our retail. One of the things that we really haven't emphasized here is our very strong targeted focus on building up our retail client base. I think this year alone, we opened up close to 50,000 additional accounts in that arena. Again, the targeted sales approach across all these asset classes bringing together Derek and Sean's team has enabled us to penetrate those markets. An interesting one, particularly in the commercial and corporate side of things, seeing about an 8% close to 10% year-on-year growth. That's a real positive for us in the context of our overall interest rate business.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gill. I just want to emphasize one thing that Derek touched upon a short while ago. And this is a testament, again, to the investment that we have made over the years in growing our sales force around the world. And that is -- and the deep relatio
componenttext: This is Gill. I just want to emphasize one thing that Derek touched upon a short while ago. And this is a testament, again, to the investment that we have made over the years in growing our sales force around the world. And that is -- and the deep relationships in education campaigns that we have run in China. The past 2 months as the upheaval in China has intensified, we have seen a very large number of traders that are seeking opportunities outside of China, and that's been driving a significant portion of the international growth that Bryan is referring to here. You're also seeing the open interest for the entire exchange growing significantly, which is another thing that you did not see in the years that you mentioned, right? So these things, together with the product development that has been done across-the-board, is what I would say differentiates us in this environment from the past ones.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And let me just give you my -- this is Terry Duffy, short take on that because participants are interesting, they come and go and they go from asset class to different asset class. But one of the things that we've been talking a little bit about this morn
componenttext: And let me just give you my -- this is Terry Duffy, short take on that because participants are interesting, they come and go and they go from asset class to different asset class. But one of the things that we've been talking a little bit about this morning is the growth in the open interest in our options products. And I really believe that when you look at options growth, that what's preserves your futures contracts. So that's what continues to attract new features participants. So we've done a really good job of bolstering our options products with the growth that we've seen in them. Now you've got to realize, they don't turnover is much is our futures but what they do is they help the risk management product, which is a futures contract, and you need to have bigger growth in your options in order to garner more participants in your futures, and that's exactly what we're doing. So we expect that it always goes up and down, but this is something that I have never seen in my 36-year history to see the options growth outpace the futures growth, and that's a great healthy sign for this company.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: We'll take our next question from Andrew Bond of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to follow up on Ken's question to get your take on the basis spread with LCH. Clearance activity has been a little light to start the year all the LCH, and I'm wondering if you think it's primarily related to the basis spread? It appears it's come
componenttext: I want to follow up on Ken's question to get your take on the basis spread with LCH. Clearance activity has been a little light to start the year all the LCH, and I'm wondering if you think it's primarily related to the basis spread? It appears it's come in a bit over the recent weeks, but do you think CME can meaningful grow clearing activity when the spread settles kind of around these levels? And how does it affect the interest rate compasses as a whole and then futurization, I guess?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Sean jumping in again. In terms of the basis, it has been stable in January. And it's really the level of the base is really kind of irrelevant to clients. What's much more important is just a bid offer spread they get coming in and the bid offer
componenttext: This is Sean jumping in again. In terms of the basis, it has been stable in January. And it's really the level of the base is really kind of irrelevant to clients. What's much more important is just a bid offer spread they get coming in and the bid offer spread they get coming out. And the level of rights they get coming in versus the level of rights coming out. So we don't see that as highly significant to the marketplace. One of the things we have seen is a fairly large increase in the dealer-to-dealer activity on CME Group. So we see the dealers hedging their positions on CME with each other. So if you look at that actually, on recent days, we've had dealer-to-dealer activity on our platform as much as 30% of the overall volumes. One thing I said before, again, if you look in addition to that, the migration over to the futures, I slightly misspoke. In 2012, we actually had 56% penetration of the cash treasury bond market, 66% in 2013. And then last year, 75%. So we see also a very large migration over into our futures.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the CME Group First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. I would like to turn the conference over to John Peschier. Please go ahead.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us this morning. Gill and John will spend a few minutes discussing the results, and then we will open up the call for your questions. Terry, Bryan, Derek, Sean and Kim are on the call as well and will participate in the Q&A session.
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us this morning. Gill and John will spend a few minutes discussing the results, and then we will open up the call for your questions. Terry, Bryan, Derek, Sean and Kim are on the call as well and will participate in the Q&A session. 
Before they begin, I'll read the safe harbor language. Statements made on this call and in the slides on our website that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. 
These statements are not guarantees of future performance and involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual outcomes and results may differ materially from what is expressed or implied in any forward-looking statements. 
More detailed information about factors that may affect our performance may be found in our filings with the SEC, which are available on our website. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Gill.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you Mr. Peschier, and the thank you all for joining us. It is an exceptional start to the year with a record quarterly average daily volume which is up 13% compared with an overall already strong first quarter last year. We had very balanced growth
componenttext:
Thank you Mr. Peschier, and the thank you all for joining us. It is an exceptional start to the year with a record quarterly average daily volume which is up 13% compared with an overall already strong first quarter last year. We had very balanced growth in both financial and commodity products, each up double digits. We track customer segment activity closely and in Q1, we had more than 10% growth from asset managers hedge funds, corporates, proprietary trading firms and retail points during the quarter. 
Volumes on banks was up 1% which is strong relative to the decrease in the overall trading businesses over each of the last few years. More recently, April activity has been fairly strong compared to last year end is up more than 20% in total. It is encouraging to see relatively good volumes as April has been our slowest month over the last 2 years.  Open interest remains elevated and it's up the significantly since the beginning of the year. 
This morning, I will start with our secular drivers, and then I will shift to a few product highlights. We have consistently expanded our global participation in spite of the challenging macro environment. We are very pleased with the tremendous results of from outside of the U.S. during the first quarter. We had record quarterly non-U.S. volume by far as well as the highest proportion of the business from outside of the U.S. since we started tracking the information, with more than 25% in the first quarter compared to 23% in the first quarter of last year. 
In Europe, we had a very strong first quarter activity, with volume increasing 28% from 2.3 million contracts per day last year to more than $2.9 million per day this year. The increase was led by equities which jumped 70%, and energy was up almost 60%. 
In Asia, energy was up 75% and equities grew by about 70%, with metals rising more than 30%. Focusing on Asia for a moment, we have been discussing the opportunity to expand our user base to include Chinese firms and entities for many years. Our focus started primarily with intermediaries, and we are now engaging directly with asset managers, hedge funds and other entities there. We generally look at our trading data in terms of what we see through mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan.  In Q1, we reached approximately 200,000 contracts per day combined, which is up from 100,000 contracts per day in Q1 of 2014 and 125,000 contracts last year. 
Our most notable recent success is in our energy franchise, where we have seen mainland China average daily volume increase from less than 10,000 contracts in the middle of last year to more than 30,000 contracts in Q1. 
A highlight from Hong Kong activity is in our equity business, with average daily volume there more than doubling to almost 25,000 contracts per day in Q1. The surge in the volume is great to see, and we are very fortunate to have highly appealing products to offer these clients. Based on the challenges in China over the last year, we believe many of these firms are comfortable trading in our regulated markets and benefiting from the significant liquidity we have around the clock. 
Speaking of that, in addition to the country of origin information we share with you, we also track electronic volume throughout the 24-hour trading day. In Q1, volumes during Asian hours grew by almost 30%, while activity during European hours rose 60%. Liquidity begets liquidity, and we are displaying deeper electronic markets in both futures and more recently, options around the clock. 
Turning to our efforts in options, we remain a strong leader compared to other global exchanges with Q1 options volume hitting a record 3.5 million contracts per day which is up 22%, with electronic options average daily volume rising 26% to a record 1.8 million contracts. The continued electronification of our options franchise has enabled us to further globalize participation in our options markets, with our European Options volume up 36%, and Asian Options volumes up 25% in Q1. 
Our continued investment in systems enhancements, new products and client education are driving significantly increased usage of our options products from end user, with the volumes from hedge funds and asset managers up 34% and up 29%, respectively. 
A couple of quick points on our financial and commodity products, starting with interest rates. Volume rose up 9% to more than 8 million contracts a day and revenue increased by 14%, with Eurodollars leading the way. We hit record levels of open interest in Q1 in our rates business, driven by Eurodollar options and Treasury futures which hit all-time highs. We also had very strong options activity with the highest quarterly volume ever, and the reached a record percentage of the options trading on Globex in March, with 71% electronic in Treasuries, and 25% electronic in Eurodollars. So far in a bill, the electronic percentage of Eurodollar options has grown to 27%. 
On the product development front, we mentioned our launch of the Ultra 10-year contract in our last earnings call. This product has continued to gain momentum, and has attracted attention with several articles written over the last month related to this innovative new products. 
In addition, we are pleased we cleared our first Swaptions trade this month, and we take this as yet another example of innovating and being first to market with a customer-led solution. We held a Swaptions customer webinar that attracted over 500 participants with significant follow-up discussions, and we had a number of productive client events related to the product. Our dollar rate swaps market share reached the highest level in March that we have seen over the last 6 months, and we had a 15% pickup in revenue capture in swaps clearing versus Q4 last year. Lastly, we are actively involved with a working group of intermediaries and customers on a potential repo clearing offering. As that develops over the next quarters, we will share additional information. 
Turning to equities, we are pleased to the start of the year with Q1 volume up 28% and April up more than 30%. We have had solid activity in equity options which grew 20% during the quarter. 
In Q1, our S&P 500 options market share versus CBOE expanded to 29.4% from 27.8% last year. Open interest in equity options rose 13% compared to the prior year, and our new BTIC order type continues to perform overall, and traded 20,000 contracts for the first time on March 31. 
Moving on to our commodities portfolio. These business alliance overall were up 13%. Energy has been particularly strong with record Q1 average daily volume of 2.5 million contracts, and April has continued to be robust with volumes up almost 40%. WTI futures had a record quarter averaging about 1.2 million contracts per day and gasoline futures activity was also at a record level. I mentioned options earlier and within energy, we had record WTI Options volume of over 200,000 contracts per day, and more than 145,000 contracts per day on Globex. 
Our natural gas options were up 38% during the quarter and we had a record percentage of volume traded electronically there. Additionally, we set a record number of large open interest holders in our energy futures in Q1. Our metals business was also a standout in the first quarter with volumes up 23%.  Our Precious Metals average daily volume a was up 26%, led by options which rose 36% in Q1. 
As many of you know, we have made significant inroads into base and ferrous metals businesses, and we continue to expand our presence in these key growth areas. Our copper business is up 11%, and we hit a new open interest record during Q1.  We continue to outperform our primary competitor in this market, where we have posted faster growth in copper in each of the last 5 quarters. 
In aluminum, we continued to expand our suite of aluminum offerings, achieving record volumes and increasing our open interest fivefold in the last 12 months.  And in iron ore, leveraging our customer value proposition of global electronic trading of futures and options and customer anonymity, we have had growing open interest and a record trading there of almost 13,000 contracts. We have now achieved iron ore market share of 10% in Q1, up from just 3% in 2015, as we continue to successfully expand and diversify our global suite of metals products. 
Financially, agricultural products have been particularly strong in April, and are tracking toward a must the average volume record for the month after a slow start to the -- trading has taken off base in production on uncertainty in South America, where wet conditions in Argentina and dry conditions in Brazil are causing concerns. We had 2 consecutive record trading days last week in the overall complex with almost 3 million contracts including record soybean product volume above [ph] 1.5 million contracts on one of those space. Electronic Ag options are surging up from near 130,000 in April last year to more than 250,000 daily so far this April. 
Importantly, open interest in soybean and corn futures are up 16% [ph] and 8%, respectively, from last year. Financially last week, we reached an all-time high in large open interest holders in agricultural products. 
In summary, we continue to work with our customers on bringing innovative risk management solutions for the marketplace, and our product diversity is unparalleled. John will touch on our progress to continue to streamline our infrastructure costs to relocate our expenses to growth initiatives and to further innovate in our businesses. 
With that, I'm gonna turn the call over to John to discuss the financials. Thank you.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you Gill and good morning, everyone everyone per cart the must be intensely focused on 3 things: Driving global the revenue growth, operating our businesses as efficiently as you can and returning excess capital to shoulders in a consistent way. As
componenttext:
Thank you Gill and good morning, everyone everyone per cart the must be intensely focused on 3 things: Driving global the revenue growth, operating our businesses as efficiently as you can and returning excess capital to shoulders in a consistent way. As Gill mentioned, we had a tremendous start of the year with strong and balanced revenue growth. 
Total revenue was up 11% compared to a very strong quarter of last year, while total adjusted expense rose just 3%. Our adjusted operating margin expanded to 65%, and adjusted EPS of $1.15 was up 17%. Our rate per contract for the first quarter was $0.756, down 4% from by $0.789 in Q4, as our overall ADV rose 29% sequentially. The biggest impact member versus nonmember mix and volume discounts tiers this quarter due to do large increase in activity. 
Compared to the fourth quarter, our members volume grew 30% and nonmembers jumped 23%. In addition, we had higher volume discounts in Q1 relative to Q4 as a result of significant growth in certain products. 
Market data revenue was up 4.5% compared to Q1 last year and in line with our guidance. We continue to monitor this line carefully as we are seeing some rationalization as we bring all customers in line with the full price offering. And we are seeing some screen declines due to recent bank staff reductions. 
Adjusted operating expenses for the quarter totaled $327 million, up 3% driven primarily by an $8 million increase in licensing and other fee agreements. Excluding license fees, our total expense year-over-year was approximately flat and as a reminder, our annual guidance was 1% increase on that basis. We ended the quarter with approximately 2,600 employees with the majority of the hiring done in India and Belfast, which is part of our plan to reduce the technology expense while improving service by staffing in those lower cost locations and reducing contractors. 
Our compensation ratio for Q1 came in at 14.1%, compared to 16.1% for the full year of 2015. 
Looking at the nonoperating income and expense line, our ownership in the S&P Dow Jones joint venture drove more than $26 million in net earnings from unconsolidated subsidiaries which is up 13% from the prior year. We are pleased with the investment we've made in the index business while also assuring we continue to offer the world's leading index futures products on CME. 
Now turning to investment income. We had a meaningful increase in investment income, driven almost entirely by the returns generated through reinvestment of cash performance bonds and guarantee fund contributions. The rise in short-term rates at the end of the year resulted in an increase in investment income of $17 million. 
During Q1, we had returned approximately $10 million of that 2 clearing firms, which is displayed on the income statement under other nonoperating expense. This amount is anticipated to increase as our investment returns grow. We recently received approval to establish an account directly at the Fed. At this point, the account will only be for clearing firm house positions held in cash. We are currently in the process of operationalizing the accounts with the Fed. When effective, we expect to pass a higher rate the clearing members for their in-house positions and then we do today. Cash he;d and segregated customer accounts will continue to be invested through commercial banks and U.S. treasury securities as they are now. 
We expect that he house accounts will be operational in the next month or so. As in the past, we plan to continue to passthrough with the majority of there earnings back to the clearing members. 
Turning to taxes, for the quarter, we ended at 36.3%, slightly below our guidance. And now to the balance sheet. During Q1, we paid almost $1.2 billion in dividends to shoulders, including our variable dividend and the first regular dividend. At the end of the first quarter, we had $1.33 billion in cash, restricted cash and marketable securities. We added $130 million during the quarter driven by do sale-leaseback transaction of our data center with Cyrus 1. 
During the first quarter, capital expenditures, net of a result improvement allowances were $16 million. As we continue to leverage more software and infrastructure as a service which is included in expense. We continue our intense focus on efficiency with the sale of our office buildings over the last few years and more recently, our data center, we are taking an asset-light approach which will allow us to focus on running our core business. 
In 2015, we delayered the management structure, closed futures pits, reduced marketing costs and focused on data center consolidation. So far this year, we have completed the sale of our data center, sublet excess office space in Chicago, announce the closure of our trading stores in New York at year end, and have begun to offshore some positions, reducing compensation and consulting costs. With the sale and leaseback of our data center, we will continue to operate our trading and clearing functions as well as our collocation business, and we will continue to receive the corresponding collocation revenue.  From an earnings perspective, this transition is approximately neutral. 
In terms of expenses, we will see in a net reduction in total quarterly expenses of about $1 million primarily in depreciation, and we expect the corresponding increase under interest expense. 
Turning to the New York floor, we will save approximately $5 million of expense annually beginning in 2017 and possibly, another $3 million per year if we can successfully sublease the space. 
In summary, I'm very pleased with the hard work this quarter across the entire business. As you know operating leverage in our business is significant, and this was clearly evidenced by the margin on incremental revenue of approximately 90%. We have outlined many positives going forward, including building liquidity around the clock and from around the world, innovating new products, getting access to the Fed accounts which should benefit both our intermediaries and our shoulders, and continuing to focus on our efficiency strategy. 
With that, we'd like to open up the call for your questions. Given the number of analysts who cover us, we ask a limit yourself to 1 question, so we can get to everyone. Please for free to get back into the queue if you have any further questions. Thank you.

And the with that focus that we have, we continued to remain opportunistic with respect to any kind of opportunities that we might see that makes sense for both our sales, our shoulders as well as our clients.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, Dan, this is John jumping in. We will get both organic and inorganic growth opportunities all the time. And really, it's about creating shoulder value in the best way possible. So we look at acquisitions in particular. We look at it from obviou
componenttext: All right, Dan, this is John jumping in. We will get both organic and inorganic growth opportunities all the time. And really, it's about creating shoulder value in the best way possible. So we look at acquisitions in particular. We look at it from obviously, multiple valuation metrics is accretive over time to earnings. Does it create value by looking at cash flow models. So we look at kind of return thresholds. We usually use about 9% to 10% is kind of the threshold that we look at. But I think for us, it's -- are we creating shoulder value? how is the best way to get from a strategic perspective, where we wanna be -- is it growing the business organically, investing the business organically -- or is it purchasing good services or another company from somebody else? So that's what we do look at.

componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Rich. Expense control and running our businesses as efficiently as possible is a very big focus of the entire management team, and it's really become part of our DNA. When we look at the expenses, the first quarter tends to be a slower water in terms of expenses as we build up and projects get launched the second and third quarters. But if you look at Slide 14, you could see the results of our focus on expenses. You can see that over time, we've had expanding operating margins and we've got incremental margins last year of 112%, and 90% incremental margins this quarter, and operating margins around 65%. So it's been a large focus of ours. In terms of the guidance, you know we are -- we have guided to a very modest 1% increase in expenses x of license fees. That's we are not adjusting guidance at this time. But we are intensely focused on the business, and the running the business as efficiently as possible. And what this does is this allows us to free up cost for growth initiatives and some of the growth initiatives Gill outlined in his prepared remarks. And for example, Swaptions are something that we'll be launching that may be -- Derek maybe -- Sean can comment on as an example of what we are working on.

componenttext: Yes, the sure. Mexican peso, we launched a little over a year ago, it's doing extremely well. We did our first Swaptions trade very recently. We're very excited how that will develop over the coming 2 quarters. And then in addition to that, we're working very closely with the marketplace on repo clearing as Gill mentioned in his remarks. So we're talking to and working closely with the same set of folks that the we've worked with in order to launch our successful interests we rate swap clearing initiative. And we're looking at replicating that the with solving a lot of the marketplace usuals in the repo, in -- particularly in the Treasury repo market similarly.

Access to the Fed accounts will be for house positions held in cash, so to the extent that, that cash balance increases, so there is an opportunity for us to earn more. And we'll be able to provide more color on how much is about that the impact next quarter when the Fed accounts become operational. But to give you an idea about 20% of $138 billion  in collateral is house account related. Maybe, Kim, if you can comment on the Fed account.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's Derek here. I would say, we're absolutely pleased, but not fully satisfied with the growth that we continue to impact here on the energies business. I mean we have -- not only have grown to record levels into Q1, we've increased our large open
componenttext: Sure. It's Derek here. I would say, we're absolutely pleased, but not fully satisfied with the growth that we continue to impact here on the energies business. I mean we have -- not only have grown to record levels into Q1, we've increased our large open interest orders. And it's been pretty strong growth. We've as in the quarter about the benefit of of the overall brought market adoption increasingly towards WTI, with the result of lifting of the export ban in the U.S. That's actually significantly increased participation in our markets on the futures as well as the option side. But in terms of where we're going outside of that options has been a significant area of growth for us inside the energies business, and are actually also directed to some of the comments that into that in his prepared remarks, we are aware on how we're globalizing our footprint right now. If you what where the growth of our business is coming from, our EMEA business for agri -- for energy business up over 40% that's outperforming the business as a whole. What's really exciting is investment that we've made in boots in the ground, so stampings and product sales in Asia for us -- is bearing significant fruit.  Our Asian energy processes of 82% year-on-year. And that's a significant growth in almost every major trading center. I was in Shanghai and Singapore last week, meeting a lot of clients, and we are content to be able to attract them with our functionality, both in the futures as well as the option side and the broad-based participation in our market. So we talked a lot of the WTI story. There's a nat gas story, there is a gasoline story -- we set an all-time record in our gasoline futures as well as. So it's broad-based growth, its global growth and it's across our asset class in the presence of building OID and large open interest holders.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: I would add to that on the international side within Asia, for example, we are see growth coming from each of our client segments in the energy quadrant, up 31% [ph]; banks interestingly enough, up 104%; hedge funds is 96%, corporate firms coming in 88%; retail, 85%. We're seeing similar activities coming out of Europe. So for example, in the hedge fund and the asset management community, 26% growth, specifically in the energy quadrant, so it goes to our sales penetration and efforts in that regard in terms of how we're targeted our focus -- and our campaigns in these areas.

componenttext: Thanks, Alex. When we provided guidance last year, we provided a range because it's very difficult to predict. We had given guidance at 4% to 5% growth rates. We came in this quarter up 4.5% from Q1 last year, which is in line with our guidance. We are seeing pressure as customers move to our full priced offering is with a decline in screen counts as banks lay off staff, as you probably heard from the banks' earnings calls. So we're very focused and working hard on our data business, but we are seeing some headwinds as indicated.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 1 on the -- primarily on the Asia question. Thanks for all disclosure and that is a good discussion you had about some of the progress there, but I guess if you can think about or try to highlight how big you think this market can eventually be for C
componenttext: Just 1 on the -- primarily on the Asia question. Thanks for all disclosure and that is a good discussion you had about some of the progress there, but I guess if you can think about or try to highlight how big you think this market can eventually be for CME in terms of penetration rates? Obviously, that was recently has been, especially strong. But do you see this as just from a -- say, an ADV perspective, being able to become as large as Europe let's say in the say next 2, 3 years? And can you just talk about some of that penetration opportunity? And then also related to -- John, I think you cited more projects and growth initiatives spend later in the year as part of that -- included in that spending plan?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Brian, this is Gill. I'm going to start and I'm going to ask Bryan to basically expand more, as to where we're seeing growth, specifically. If we look at the product, all opportunity set, if you look at the opportunity in terms of the product that w
componenttext: Sure. Brian, this is Gill. I'm going to start and I'm going to ask Bryan to basically expand more, as to where we're seeing growth, specifically. If we look at the product, all opportunity set, if you look at the opportunity in terms of the product that we have across all the asset classes that we have, we have fairly relevant products for all of our clients in all places around the world. Within Asia, specifically, we have been focused over the last few years on China but what we have not talked about is the sales effort that Bryan will go a little bit into other parts of Asia, which I would say is more developed in terms of the education side of things. Korea comes to mind. China, we have given you some numbers this quarter specific to China. This are accounts that are based in China but they may be trading. They probably will be trading from outside of China. As China continues to expand its policies for excess, you would see that number grow. The timing behind that remains to be seen. But as we sit here now, China is allowing and has allowed their intermediaries as well as their direct account, such as the hedge funds, the prop and the commercial entities to establish operations outside of China. And that's the flow that we're seeing. India is an untapped opportunity at this time. There are very significant changes of foot in India that will also lend themselves and translate into all opportunities for us. So with that broad view of China -- and I'm only talking Asia's -- areas in which you will see the highest impact. I'm going to turn it over to Bryan to talk about some of the volume flows that we're seeing that are driving the high rate of growth of there.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So with respect to the efforts in Greater China and Hong Kong and specifically, Hong Kong, we're seeing revenues that are up about 51%, 56% growth in our volume. That's being driven from energy, equities as well as some of our interest rate products. With
componenttext: So with respect to the efforts in Greater China and Hong Kong and specifically, Hong Kong, we're seeing revenues that are up about 51%, 56% growth in our volume. That's being driven from energy, equities as well as some of our interest rate products. Within the segments, the growth is really coming from props, a growing number of private hedge funds and private managers have always been very working closely with our intermediaries to help bring that business into our markets. We are still some good traction in terms of liberalization of central state-owned enterprises, for example, as always we're permission up until about 2 years ago, at 31, now it's about 112 or in that area so we are seeing that as additional opportunity. Sovereign wealth funds and asset managers are increasingly growing their business because. And again, we are focusing in that area and really building on opportunities to work with corporate, particularly insurance companies. We see more Chinese banks that are inquiring about trading our products and also, looking to build their efforts, inquiring about OTC clearing with us, which is a very good sign. Within Taiwan, year-to-date volume and revenue was up about 40% and 36%, respectively. The main driver is in those areas where equities, FX, energy and interest rates -- the main participants are banks, asset managers. And again, we are still some good opportunities with insurance companies. There's been some progress within Taiwan in terms of allowing securities firms to offer global futures, so we're working very closely with their intermediaries to bring that business into our group. Within Japan, we've seen a consistent growth of about 7%. Revenues are up about 32%. You know you've got to keep in mind, Japan is the second-biggest holder for U.S. debt so there's great opportunities there. Main drivers have been from banks, and we're seeing some nice growth coming from asset managers. Gill alluded to in Korea. We continued to see very nice growth coming out of Korea. Gill was -- 2 years ago, there were no Korea FCMs that had an average monthly volume about 100,000 contracts. Today, we're happy to say that we have 8 firms that are providing at least 100,000 sites per month which is a great progress. And the drivers in that area are equities, rates, foreign currency and energy. Singapore, it's up about 18% coming out of that region. We're seeing some nice growth coming from the banks, in particular as well as proprietary firms and corporates and commercials. Another area that we're very excited about is Australia. We really haven't mentioned that. Our volume this year in Australia is up 12%, and our revenues are up, I think, approximately 50%, if my memory serves me correctly. The top 3 products are interest rates, and some equities. And ag is up about 27%, foreign currencies are up about 39%. Our main focus in working with Australia again is within the asset management community, hedge funds and the banks.

componenttextpreview: Question on your margins. So I mean, a great margin quarter, 65%, I think that's one of the best results you guys have ever had. If we can kind of bigger picture and you guys keep delivering double-digit volume growth and 90% incremental margin, your marg
componenttext: Question on your margins. So I mean, a great margin quarter, 65%, I think that's one of the best results you guys have ever had. If we can kind of bigger picture and you guys keep delivering double-digit volume growth and 90% incremental margin, your margins going to move up fast in a hurry. So I'm just wondering, is there a limit where you guys are really comfortable about taking the margin too before we start seeing a fairly sizable increase in the expenses? Or is that really nothing for us to be focused on at this point in time?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. This is John. yes, we're limited by 100% -- is our limit. But in all seriousness, we are -- we continue to run the business as efficiently as possible. As you could see from the amount of volume we've been able to hand over without any issues, we
componenttext: Thanks. This is John. yes, we're limited by 100% -- is our limit. But in all seriousness, we are -- we continue to run the business as efficiently as possible. As you could see from the amount of volume we've been able to hand over without any issues, we have been able to handle that this quarter without any incidents. So I think for us, we do have natural increases to our cost and over time, the inflationary things, salaries and wages and the allied. But we are -- we provide a tremendous amount of value to our clients and so as more liquidity comes into the marketplace, there's more training training that occurs, which is a tremendous benefit to our business. And the amount of volume that were able to handle -- we've been proven out to be able to handle that. Other things that kind of impact the margin is also the license fees we pay on equity contracts primarily, so there is some share that impacts kind of our margin level. But there's nothing artificial out there that prevents that from going higher.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Gill. I'll just just add to what John said. John is spot on with respect to the current operating structure that we have and products as we continue to innovate across the asset classes. But as we roll out new and innovative products or ser
componenttext: Chris, this is Gill. I'll just just add to what John said. John is spot on with respect to the current operating structure that we have and products as we continue to innovate across the asset classes. But as we roll out new and innovative products or services in response to what our client needs are and in conjunction with the capital efficiency goal that we have for our clients, the repo clearing services one -- is one such thing that, and that's a separate infrastructure from what we currently have. John has fine-tuned the current infrastructure to hum like you're seeing it now. And within that construct, the operating margin can absolutely grow. But it is to introduce marketings for quite base, you may see a slight reduction depending upon the success of the products and services that we roll out.

With respect to pricing pressure, it being too high. So we don't think that's the issue. We think these firms are rationalizing their needs over time. Bryan, you might want to add?

componenttextpreview: Hey, this is Derek. I'll for your question. No -- I think, you see when we what the status of our businesses, if you look at 6 months prior to NFX launches, or we were averaging a nat gas options where they're making hard push right now, that's 70,000 con
componenttext: Hey, this is Derek. I'll for your question. No -- I think, you see when we what the status of our businesses, if you look at 6 months prior to NFX launches, or we were averaging a nat gas options where they're making hard push right now, that's 70,000 contracts a day. If you look at the last 6 months, our ADV is close to 100,000 contacts. So we've grown that business 40% over the course of time that NFX is coming to the market. And to the extent we've got the fastest-growing part of that nat gas options business for us is the electronic nature of the business, a record 20% of a nat gas business trading electronically. They're driving that 40% growth. If you look at what NFX is putting up some block business, it's not electronic and it's only on the financial settled side. So given the fact that we've added 30,000 contracts ADV since pre-launch of NFX, the post-launch -- and they are doing 12,000 to 15,000, we're not seeing any real feedback from customers asking us to do anything different, other than to continue to scale our infrastructure electronically and grow the business.

componenttext: Yes. I'll start and ask Kim to add here. The capital efficiency -- title has at least 2 or 3 things beneath that, that might be helpful for you to think about, I would say, in terms of the opportunities being efficient for our client base, futurization is at the top of that place. So developing products in-house that our customers can use on homework capital efficient basis is one of the things that we have been doing and we'll continue to actually do. If we look at the compression services that we implemented not too long ago up to this point in time, you have $21 trillion in notional value that have been compressed over time. And if you look at the performance of the OTC market itself, it has taken on uptick from the fourth quarter of last year. Now this value proposition, this group of value proposition that I just described, no one else can provide that. Be compression in conjunction with the cross-margining and in conjunction with the futurization opportunity. So I think from that perspective, we are quite excited as the interest rate environment, the environment continues to shift.

componenttext: Yes. So we are always focused on the clients and the value that we had to clients and therefore, we'll also always focused on market share. So in each and everyone of our businesses, is we are continuously focused on our direct competitors but also substitute products, and making sure that we add the most value. So while we may not have talked about this as actively as before, this is are in the case of the will very closely put in particular, if you look at the business, we're very focused on the ability, right, to gross margin obviously the underlying futures against the options, as most efficient platform possible, we are continuously focused on TCA or total cost analysis. We've talked about this in each our our different business lines. If you recall, the beginning of last year, Granites Associates did a big study that looked at our interest rate futures, as always be the lowest cost relative to the interest rate swaps, interest rates -- in terms of underlying risk. Similarly, we have come out last year with some quick big picture, and we did an update this year, again, with the big picture. But we're very showing that our -- as an example, our equity futures far more efficient for investors for getting exposure to the equity market than ETFs. So we're continuing to look at the substitute products, both from a customer or client to value proposition but also from a market share perspective.
