componenttext: For a follow-up, I guess. Want to go to your equities business for a minute. On that slide that you had on equities, I think it's Page 10, you mentioned that -- on the S&P 500 options, I guess options on futures, you now have -- your market share increased relative to CBOE. I don't think you've talked about that business on a competitive basis in the past or in those terms. So just wondering if this is an active focus of yours to kind of look at that market and compete more aggressively and maybe court away the user base from the securities-based options to the futures market. So any color there will be interesting.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're always focused on the clients and the value that we add to clients and therefore we're also always focused on market share. So in each and every one of our businesses, we're continuously focused on our direct competitors but also substitute
componenttext: Yes, so we're always focused on the clients and the value that we add to clients and therefore we're also always focused on market share. So in each and every one of our businesses, we're continuously focused on our direct competitors but also substitute products and making sure that we add the most value. So while we may not have talked about this as actively before, this is certainly something that we look at very closely. In particular, if you look at that business, we're very focused on the ability, right, to cross-margin obviously the underlying futures against the options. As the most efficient platform possible, we're continuously focused on TCA or total cost analysis. We've talked about this across each our different business lines. If you recall, the beginning of last year, Greenwich Associates did a big study that looked at our interest rate futures as always being the lowest cost relative to the interest rate swaps industry in terms of representing risk. Similarly, we have come out last year with something called The Big Picture and then we did an update this year, again, with The Big Picture. But we're showing that our, as an example, our equity future's far more efficient for investors for getting exposure to the equity market than the ETFs. So we're continuing to look at the substitute products both from a customer client value proposition, but also from a market share perspective.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the CME Group Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. I would like to turn the conference over to John Peschier. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the CME Group Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. I would like to turn the conference over to John Peschier. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us this morning. Gill and John will spend a few minutes discussing the results, and then we will open up the call for your questions. Terry, Bryan, Derek and Sean are on the call as well and will participate in the Q&A session.Befo
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us this morning. Gill and John will spend a few minutes discussing the results, and then we will open up the call for your questions. Terry, Bryan, Derek and Sean are on the call as well and will participate in the Q&A session.
Before they begin, I'll read the safe harbor language. Statements made on this call and in the slides on our website that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. These statements are not guarantees of future performance and involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual outcomes and results may differ materially from what is expressed or implied in any forward-looking statements. More detailed information about factors that may affect our performance may be found in our filings with the SEC, which are available on our website.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Gill.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mr. Peschier, and thank you all for joining us. It is another solid quarter for us. Average daily volume in Q2 rose by 13%, the same growth rate as our record first quarter.We had double-digit growth again from each of our buy-side client gro
componenttext:
Thank you, Mr. Peschier, and thank you all for joining us. It is another solid quarter for us. Average daily volume in Q2 rose by 13%, the same growth rate as our record first quarter.
We had double-digit growth again from each of our buy-side client groups, including asset managers, hedge funds, proprietary trading firms, corporate and retail. Despite the recent slowdown and volatility post-Brexit as measured by the -- we are tracking up 10% compared with last July.
We were pleased to opening record in the second quarter of over 116 [ph] million contracts, and we are near peaks in our last opening -- data in several product areas. This morning, I will start with our -- drivers and then I will shift to a few product highlights. We have consistently expanded our global participation despite of the challenging macro environment. We saw robust electronic trading activity outside of the U.S. with Asia up 21% versus Q2 last year. Latin America rose 16%, and Europe rose 12%. Following the Brexit announcement, we had significant activity from outside of the U.Swith 5.3 million contracts traded from Europe and 1.9 million contracts traded from Asia the day after.
In Q2, the electronic volume from outside of the U.S. is 24%. In July, that has jumped to 27%; and the day after Brexit, 29% of the activity was outside of the U.S.
In Europe, volumes in fiber product areas grew by more than 20% with the strongest growth in energy and equity with year-to-date ADV up 38% and 35%, respectively.
In Asia, future ADV and energy rose by more than 140%, and metals volumes jumped more than 80%. Latin America growth has also led by energy. In addition to the country of origin information that we shared with you, we also track electronic volume throughout the 24-hour trading day.
In Q2, volume during Asian hours grew by almost 40% from 260,000 contracts per day last year to 360,000 this quarter. During European hours, from 11:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m central time, volume rose from 750,000 per day to 1.1 million a day, up almost 45%.
Turning to our -- options, we remain the leader relative to other global exchanges with Q2 options rising 15% and electronic options average daily volume rising 23% to 1.7 million contracts.
In Q2, the percentage of options at trading on Globex reached an all-time high of 57%, up from 51% in Q1. We saw the highest electronic percentage to date in interest rates, energy and metals. Agriculture options reached a record quarterly ADV of 345,000, up 26% from the prior year.
Lastly, in June, we had the highest month ever in total weekly options products with 495,000 contracts per day, up 57%.
Moving on to our commodities portfolio, we had a very impressive quarter with energy, ag and metals, each up more than 20% in revenue. We also set new records a large company just in metals and ag, reaffirming that global customers continue to manage their commodities markets risk exposures at CME Group. We track substitute products very closely, and we have outperformed peers in crude futures, good options, natural gas futures, natural gas options, gold and copper so far in 2016.
Energy was particularly strong with Q2 average daily volume of 2.3 million contracts, and July has continued to be robust with volumes up 20%. In Q2, crude was up 38%, natural gas rose 17%, and refined products increased 18%.
The European and Asian activity and energy mentioned earlier highlight our extremely focused attention on our customers globally and the growing relevance of our product set.
Growth in energy options has been meaningful. WTI options volume rose more than 20% to more than 180,000 contracts per day, while natural gas options were up almost 20% as well.
Within energy options, we have grown from 49% electronic in Q1 to 53% in Q2 and up to 57% so far this month.
Energy ADV in the second quarter was the second-highest quarter ever behind the record first quarter this year.
Our metals business during the quarter was phenomenal. Volume was up 41%, and the -- revenues rose 35%. Our precious metals average daily volume was up 43%, while copper rose 33% versus a year ago. Options activity was strong, up 32% compared to last year. Metals had a second best quarter ever, and we had outperformed substitute products at exchanges by a significant amount. We were also able to achieve multiple all-time opening records in copper, as well as set the all-time records for large opening holders in both gold and silver in July.
Last but not least, our agriculture business had its highest volume quarter in our history. Ag options rose 26% and futures were up 22%. Soybeans led the way, up 49%; while corn, soybean meal and hard grade each grew more than 20%. It is worth noting that there are increasing expectations the likelihood of La Nina. We would expect that to impact both our cultural volumes, as well as benefiting our natural gas markets.
Turning to financial products and starting with interest rates, average daily volume in Q2 was up 3% and year-to-date, we are up 7%.
Within Eurodollar options, volume increased 28% during the second quarter. Recently, we have had progress developing liquidity and trading in the spring with the electronic percentage increasing from 23% to 25% from Q1 to Q2. Also, the electronic volume during the U.S. hours from the -- open continues to increase significantly. Futures continue to be robust. As we have seen, expectations move around before, during and after the Brexit vote.
Fed funds futures averaged more than 142,000 contracts per day in Q2, up almost 140%. In addition, we spoke about the successful launch of the Ultra 10-Year product last quarter, and volume has dropped from 35,000 contracts per day to over 60,000 and July as tracking at the same level.
We launched options clearing in the second quarter with 5 approved clearing members, and we've now cleared dealer to dealer and customer trades. In addition to Swaptions, our recently launch Brazilian real IRS clearing offering began scaling in June and is now at 24 participants would have cleared the product thus far.
We continue to outperform other markets indicating the proportion of activities shifting to our interest rate futures and options. For example, while we are up 7% year-to-date in interest rate volumes, global dealer-to-clients swap trading volume were down 10% in the dollar fix to floating market. We continue to capture market share in treasury switch we talked about before as cash treasuries are down 5%, while our treasury futures are flat. Our opening interest rates continues to hit record elevated levels above $63 million contracts in March and June, while rate related opening interest at most of our exchanges peaked several years ago.
Turning to equities. ADV was up 25% in Q2 to almost 3 million contracts. And as I mentioned, we have had great participation from clients around the world. We had solid activity in equity options, which grew 24% during the quarter. We were particularly pleased with record of more than 440,000 equity options that trading post-Brexit before the U.S. stock market even opened. In addition, last week we announced the launch of S&P 500 total return index futures and the S&P 500 carrier adjusted total return index futures. These innovative products are intended to mimic the economics of a total return swaps in futures form, allowing swap dealers in the end clients to avoid higher cost as a result of new swap margin rules that are expected on September 1.
This is another example of CME Group's ongoing commitment to meet the changing needs of our clients in an evolving global marketplace. The S&P 500 total return index futures will be available to trade by B -- which is basis trade index at close and will further expand the U.S. major index -- offering, which trade at a record $32 billion in -- during Q2. Lastly, our FX business is down 7% in Q2 as trading environment was challenging pre-Brexit. So far this year, we have outperformed the 2 largest FX platforms in terms of trading activity versus last year. Our FX markets performed very well during the post-Brexit day, but the markets were active and we had record British activity with more than 500,000 contracts traded that day.
Speaking of Brexit, we were very busy after the results came in, particularly during the pre-U.S. hours. We had a record 350 million messages to process. And as a slide in presentation shows, we handled it without any issues. This is a tribute to our hard-working colleagues, who already handled strong activity when volatility spikes.
We have had a tremendous opportunity during the last few months to deeply engage with our global clients as markets growth continues to evolve with uncertainty post-Brexit and also the upcoming implementation of margin for uncleared swaps. We have been talking to folks about the greater regulatory certainty under U.S. regulation. And based on the results again this quarter, it was clear customers at every continent are comfortable with the U.S. regime. This was further solidified with recognition and permanent QCCP status in Europe that we received in June.
The next potential catalyst for increased exchange trading and swaps clearing is in about 5 weeks when the first phase begins in the interdealer market requiring daily initial margin in the region margin to be exchanged on a bilateral common non centrally cleared portfolios in the U.S..
There will be 10 million [ph] margin period of risk that will be put in place for uncleared swaps, and there will be less netting available compared to the 5-day period for cleared swaps and generally 1 to 2 days for futures and options.
Based on many client discussions, we are accelerating internal product development to try to create solutions that can provide relief for participants, including intermediaries and end clients. I mentioned the S&P 500 total return index futures launched prior September 1. Within our interest rate and FX areas, we are examining multiple new product ideas and looking at product construction. Within FX, opportunities we are working on include clearing for OTC FX options and nondeliverable forward. In addition, within rates, we believe this could be a catalyst for our Swaptions business, and they're getting inbound calls from customers about other ideas. Lastly, I mentioned repo clearing last quarter, and we continue to make significant progress on the operational side in terms of technology and clearing, and we are working closely with large banks, asset managers and hedge funds. In addition, we are planning to be operationally prepared to launch fairly soon after regulatory approval.
In summary, we continue to expand our global footprint and product offerings to create opportunities for our clients and our shareholders. We have looked hard to position the company for success in the world that needs transparent, clear solutions for risk management now more than ever. With that, I will to turn the call over to John to discuss the financials. Thank you.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gill, good morning, everyone. Our team has been intensely focused on driving global revenue growth, operating our business as efficiently as possible and returning excess capital to our shareholders in a consistent manner.As Gill mentioned, w
componenttext:
Thank you, Gill, good morning, everyone. Our team has been intensely focused on driving global revenue growth, operating our business as efficiently as possible and returning excess capital to our shareholders in a consistent manner.
As Gill mentioned, we had another excellent quarter. Total revenue was up 11% compared to a very strong quarter in Q2 last year with 4 of our 6 product areas delivering more than 20% revenue growth. Our adjusted expenses, excluding license fees, were flat with the second quarter of last year so almost all of the incremental revenue dropped to the operating income line. Our adjusted operating margin expanded by 3 percentage points from a year ago and adjusted EPS was up more than 15% for the second quarter in a row.
This quarter, we removed amortization from our adjusted results, and we've provided a summary of the impact on prior quarters both in our earnings presentation deck, as well as in the income statement trend file we posted on our website. This change puts the reporting of our adjusted results in line with our U.S. exchange peers.
Our repo contract for the second quarter was $0.782, up from $0.756 in Q1 due primarily to a positive shift in product mix, which was slightly offset by the number mix.
Market data revenue was $103 million, up slightly from the prior quarter. Moving to expenses, excluding license fees and adjustments, our total expense was $270 million, exactly where we were in Q2 2015, which I am pleased to report along with a solid top line growth. For the first half of the year, on new spaces we were at $534 million, up about 1/2 of 1%. For the second half, I would expect expenses to be about $548 million. The increase from the first half is based on our heavier spend on customer-related activity in Q4 and the acceleration of product development, which Gill alluded to. We will be lower than our initial guidance at the beginning of the year, which included amortization and excluded license fees by $4 million.
Instead of being up 1%, we are guiding to 0.5% increase on that basis. We ended the quarter with approximately 2,640 employees, up 40 from last quarter, driven primarily by entry level hires and hires in lower cost locations.
Our competition ratio from Q2 came in at 14.5% and is down from 17% in Q2 last year. Looking at the nonoperating income and expense line, our ownership in S&P Dow Jones joint venture drove $27 million in net earnings among consolidated subsidiaries, up slightly from Q1. turning to investment income, we received $2.6 million in dividends from BB&F. In addition, our investment returns generated through reinvestment of cash performance bonds and guaranteed funds contributions during Q2, decreased sequentially to $5.2 million from $7 million in Q1.
This is a result of lower average daily investment balances from the prior quarter and our net return during Q2 was 9 basis points. While we have been approved establish an account with the Fed for house cash, it is not live yet, and we continue to work through the operational details.
Turning to taxes, for the quarter, we ended at an adjusted 36.5%, which is where we guided. And now to the balance sheet. At the end of the second quarter, we had $1.34 billion in cash, restricted cash and marketable securities. During the second quarter, capital expenditures net of leasehold improvement allowances were $20 million as we continue to leverage more software and infrastructure as a service, which is included in the expense.
We originally guided to $115 million to $120 million for the year. I'm going to reduce that by $15 million to $100 million to $105 million based on efficiency efforts and timing.
One final item I want to outline today is  the new program we have available for equity members. These firms are required to hold shares of CME Group Class A common stock in addition to seats to receive equity membership privileges.
Under the terms of the program, participants may substitute the assignment of the required shares by paying us a monthly subscription. Currently, there are 370 institutions that are required to hold CME Group Class A common shares as part of their equity membership.
A typical equity member is required to hold 20,000 shares for exchange in addition to seats. For most of the equity members, this subscription rate will be $7500 per month per exchange. This will provide choice for the firms and potentially allow them to free up capital to deploy in other ways. Each of the 370 firms will have full discretion on whether or not to principate in the program. The timing under evaluation and decision to participate is expected to lead to an orderly share release over time and should be easily absorbed by the market. As it is unclear on the participation level, we will update you next quarter on the uptake.
At a 50% participation level, we will generate an estimated $20 million of incremental annual revenue and up to $40 million if all equity members switch to monthly subscription. 
In summary, I am very pleased with the hard work this quarter across the entire business. Our secular growth drivers continue to deliver results with or without volatility, our efficiency and expenses has been excellent, and since the first of the year, we returned $1.4 billion in dividends. With that, we'd like to open up the call for your questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

componenttext: I've been called Ron recently as well. I guess, thanks, Gill, you did an extensive product volume and even geographic review of how you're doing, how well you're doing. I guess my question is, do you guys target or what new products can actually impact your volume or your revenue in a year's time frame, if you assume the -- I know this isn't reality, but if you assume a similar environment, what do you try to get -- expect to get from these new products as a company as an exchange? And then I guess, the follow-up would be which of the big ones, which products are most impactful to that?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rich, I'll start and then I'll ask both Derek and Sean to comment if they want to. I think when you talk about product innovation here, you are always facing the uncertainty of are you going to be success or not. And what the have started doing parti
componenttext: Yes, Rich, I'll start and then I'll ask both Derek and Sean to comment if they want to. I think when you talk about product innovation here, you are always facing the uncertainty of are you going to be success or not. And what the have started doing particularly in the last 5 to 7 years have a comprehensive plan and part of that planning is starting to clients on the very broad basis. In previous calls, I've spoken to you about the number of folks that tune to seminars that we put on, and that's an indication to us. And 1 example is the ultra 10-year bond that we launched and enthusiasm by the bond and the corresponding volume that we've got since launch has been great. And so we've got a pipeline of both the commodity side and the financial side, and our guys are pretty excited about some of the prospects there. So I will tell you Sean to comment on some of those things and then Mr.  Sammann can talk about others.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, in terms of the bottom line on these parts, if you look at the P&L, as Gill mentioned, we were doing 60,000 contracts a day. So you can look at our rates, our PC, which is publicly available, and you can see that we're running currently at seven --
componenttext: Sure, in terms of the bottom line on these parts, if you look at the P&L, as Gill mentioned, we were doing 60,000 contracts a day. So you can look at our rates, our PC, which is publicly available, and you can see that we're running currently at seven -- several million dollars a year in terms of revenues, in terms of the run rate. If you look at Mexican pesos, and our interest rate swaps clearing business, we now offer 19 currencies relative to the large competitor offering, 17 currencies so we got 2 now unique value propositions in terms of currencies, both the Mexican peso and the Brazil real. In terms of the Mexican peso, we have MXN 1.5 million a month is our current run rate. So while it is a small currency, it's actually having a significant impact on that business. With the Brazilian real, as Gill mentioned on the call, we're hitting a critical mass in the month of June. To put in perspective, we launched -- it takes time for the new products to gain traction relative to building a critical mass of participants. In the month of June, we had a $5 billion equivalent total volume cleared in the month of July -- sorry, that was in the month of May. Excuse me, $5 billion in the month of May. In the month of June, we had $35 billion. The Brazilian against unique value proposition relative to our largest competitor, it is a larger currency than Mexican peso, so we do expect eventually to make more in the Brazilian than we are currently making in the Mexican peso. We've had big success in our equity product that we launched in November of last year. The dividend futures, which we've spoken about are running about 1000 day. The bigger and more exciting thing relative to future growth is we've got over 50,000 contracts in open interest. In terms of -- we're trading that's on the S&P 500 in particular, we trading over 5,000 contracts a day. If you look at new products, we hope that they drive typically 3-or-so percent of our top line growth. We have other new products that we're launching with Swaptions. As I said, it takes a while to build a critical mass with the Brazilian real. It took us from August of last year until June of this year to start hitting a critical mass. We do expect with U.S. dollar swaptions to hit a critical mass hopefully in the fourth quarter and to begin to see significant growth starting then. So we see strong growth across each of our product areas with top line of 3% plus. Derek, do you want to jump in?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's from a product launch perspective, which we trended look at this in terms of the client need, market structure and what is changing the environment that provides an opportunity for us to provide a service that is not offered by someone o
componenttext: Yes, I think it's from a product launch perspective, which we trended look at this in terms of the client need, market structure and what is changing the environment that provides an opportunity for us to provide a service that is not offered by someone out there, and that's when you think about product development and opportunities is where there are global benchmarks that might be in this repair or broken benchmarks, clients not able to manage a risk the way they could. Those are market entry opportunities for us. For example, our move into aluminum 18 months ago was a result of customers not being able to access their fiscal aluminum get it out of their warehouse. So the growth in market share and revenue generation on our copper business has been largely helped by our entering the aluminum market. In fact, Miller -- announced just last month that they're going to be shifting their price benchmark for the North American aluminum procurement to a CME-based product that we launched 18 months ago. Looking forward, the other area of product opportunity and development, is where we can add products to our overall portfolio. So as Gill mentioned, we've got record revenue generation in our agriculture products business. We announced last month that we'll be launching our European we contracts on September 12 this year, and that's -- out what is already a global utilized contract with the product that addresses some of the shortcomings in the current products. So great opportunities there, and we're into our portfolio of services, making it easier from a capital perspective and operational asset perspective for our customers to manage all the risk at CME Group. That's been our focal point for product development.

I just want to like if there's any sense for what is the symbol will be part of what's been cyclical and what gives you confidence that maybe you can grow from current levels?

componenttext: Sure. As you pointed out, Chris, the regional growth story here for degree outside of the U.S. and on the commodities front is particularly strong coming from Asia in both the energy and med -- metals front. Mr. Sammann, do you want to add some detail there?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're particularly excited about the numbers we've been sharing with you guys about the commodities footprint that we're going in Asia. If you look at the energy revenues we generated year-to-date, energy revenues is now representing almost 3
componenttext: Yes, I think we're particularly excited about the numbers we've been sharing with you guys about the commodities footprint that we're going in Asia. If you look at the energy revenues we generated year-to-date, energy revenues is now representing almost 35% of the total revenues we're generating out of China and greater China as a whole, our business in greater China mean Hong Kong, China and Taiwan is that 227%. The metals business, specifically, is our second biggest revenue source in the same region. That's up 61%. So the opportunity set that we've got when we owned the benchmarks from the metal side, our ability to position ourselves as a global benchmarks in region with the sales effort that Brian and his team has been pulling forth in region to make sure that we're accessing a customer base with global liquidity, by time zone as well, that's how we see the opportunity continue to build into that community. I would also like to add that if you look at the importance of the commercial customers who work on these complex, as a whole, we continue to focus on than being a primary driver of our access because as you address those end-user customer needs, that brings the other market participants the profit to banks the others that want to be where the end-user customers are. So when you look at the revenue growth of the franchise as a whole, the record level of large open interest record level of open interest that sell, layer on top of the China growth, tells a story of globalized participation in our markets and globalizing access to those global participant based on the commercial side.

componenttext: Sure, Mike. No, it's not unusual for our cash balance to go lower in Q2. The primary reason is that we have 2 tax payments in the second quarter and for this quarter, it was $416 million. And we also have our regular dividend of $202 million that happened this quarter. So it's not unusual for Q2 to be a slower quarter in terms of cash build. So we have tremendous leverage in our business model, and we've been able to return $1.4 billion in dividends year-to-date. So, obviously, that is a cash impact.

componenttext: I'll take the market data. It's Bryan. First of all, we've been monitoring closely our subscriber base since we implemented the full fare back in January, and we're pleased to see we're not seeing any subsequent reductions or consolidations in that regard. With that in mind, we really been focused on developing new opportunities for revenue. One of the areas that we have an increased emphasis on is our development of derived data, and it's representing a very nice revenue stream for us. So you can expect to see more activities on that end. While we haven't announced any type of price increase in 2017, we will be expecting an increase that will impact certain segments and operating associated with our market data.

componenttext: So, Brian, in terms of the use obstruction plan, the purpose of the program is to provide our numbers flexibility. So the numbers either can hold our shares or they can free up those shares and pay us a subscription fee. So this gives our members a choice and how to deploy the capital. Also, it may make it easier for potential new members, especially those in the international members who may find holding these shares prohibited. So this is the of our current members, it's good for potential new members and it's good for CME because we will be generating recurring revenue from that payment. And if going to show up in our other revenue line not necessarily in the market data line, and obviously, this all is incremental to our bottom line.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A specific question on pricing. So it looks like you began charging for Brent trading in July for nonmarket makers. Can you give us some more color around what you thought it was the right time to make this move? Whether or not you've seen any material di
componenttext: A specific question on pricing. So it looks like you began charging for Brent trading in July for nonmarket makers. Can you give us some more color around what you thought it was the right time to make this move? Whether or not you've seen any material difference in client trading activity? Financial maybe change? And then lastly, whether there are any plans in the incentives for marketmakers in the future?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kyle, it's Derek. I think we've been building our market share in Brent and really building our global participation in -- and when you build markets and you enter where the incumbent is already present, you need to answer by providing incentive to make i
componenttext: Kyle, it's Derek. I think we've been building our market share in Brent and really building our global participation in -- and when you build markets and you enter where the incumbent is already present, you need to answer by providing incentive to make it easy to access the more you build to make it economically painful. So what we've done is over the last probably 24 months or so, we'd look at the traction we've got in 10%, 12%, 13%, and we've now actually rolled out our brand options market as well last quarter. And we're at a point now where we said we've got a balance sustainable participation level across the franchise as a whole. Energy is up 25%. We've always been Brent as important part of the overall story. The market is telling us that once the trade WTI and we look at the differential fortunes between what's happening between what happens on the WTI side of the fence and we're proud our business is up about 45%, 48% in -- this is up about 19% the market is only wants to trade on the WTI side of the ledger. So we've been successful with the commercial participation. And we believe at this point, we're happy to be able to start to scale back some of those incentives that the liquidity itself is sufficient to be able to maintain participation in the market. So at any time the marketmaker and some place, they're always by nature temporary. Interest successful the value proposition that will hold once you remove the incentives. I think the role performance of the franchise speaks to the success and the value we are bringing to participants.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Rob, this is John. Our view on M&A hasn't changed. We will be looking at all potential M&A to create shareholder value and grow in our strategic point of view. So we'll evaluate all opportunities. With regard to why we changed amortization, all of our
componenttext: Hi, Rob, this is John. Our view on M&A hasn't changed. We will be looking at all potential M&A to create shareholder value and grow in our strategic point of view. So we'll evaluate all opportunities. With regard to why we changed amortization, all of our U.S. exchange peers have taken amortization out of their earnings. That came out last quarter, excluding at -- removed it from their results. We thought it was important from a comparison purposes to exclude it, so that investment committee can have an apples-to-apples comparison with the other exchanges.

componenttext: When we look at your energy business, obviously, a lot of positive takeaways, fundamental and both innovation on your part. Both incumbents are now seeing competition from NASDAQ and that continues to grow of the interest due to lower pricing. headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Derek, I'll take that. I think if you start to look at the franchise as a whole, the energy business up 25%. We're seeing the significant growth uptake on the WTI side of the ledger. We're also seeing significant growth in the electronic side of our
componenttext: It's Derek, I'll take that. I think if you start to look at the franchise as a whole, the energy business up 25%. We're seeing the significant growth uptake on the WTI side of the ledger. We're also seeing significant growth in the electronic side of our business. So when you couple together the huge growth that we're seeing in the core franchise, we're seeing the large open interest holder record levels, we're seeing commercial participation and revenue generation from the commercial participants at record level, we actually find that our business is able is beyond just any particular single product size. But when you talk about individual views of nat gas itself, but our nat gas franchise year-to-date is up 12%, and -- revenue is actually down 4% in nat gas. And but when you go to a pre-FX launch, we're about 65% of the nat gas options market. NASDAQ is about 35%. If you look at the rolling 60-day average, we've actually increased our market share since -- launch where 68%, [indiscernible] 20% and FX is about 12%. So when you actually look at -- you had a 2 [ph] man race [ph] were 65% of the market, and the 3 man [ph] race were 68% of the market, that same bigger market. So when we talk to our customers, what's important to them is the full range of products and services inside the asset class. So we think about the 76% market share we had in the nat gas futures. The growth in percentage market share, which we're getting paid by our customers to deliver on top of the fact that the overall franchise and TI -- I mean, talk about the footprint were generated in China right now, that's where our customers want access to. They want to access the global prices. They want to access to a product where you have global participation from the commercial side and international footprint side, and where we are in the process of electronifying the nat gas options business because that's what makes you sticky. I want to remind everybody that when you look at the NFX value proposition, they said, we're going to do it free and we're going to do it at a block basis. But you've heard us build markets for 15 years by electronifying them. So you're thinking our nat gas options from 5% electronic to 25% of electronic over the last 18 months, that's why you're seeing this grow outside of the market share in revenue-generating products like nat gas options and you'll see us continue to push that with the overall revenue story as well. So our revenue growth is up 21% in energy as a whole, -- revenue growth is up 14% in energy, and NASDAQ is in energy, I guess, either flat, maybe negative based on the incentives that came out.

componenttext: Yes, sure, thank you. Just a couple of things to point out as it relates the CapEx. I mean, on a year-over-year basis, CapEx is down but that is really driven by our New York City staff space build out after the sale of the NYMEX building. So if you exclude all the real estate, our technology spend for the first quarter is slightly half higher than the second quarter last year and about $4 million higher than the first half of last year. So we're continuing to invest in our technology footprint. And I think the second half either we are making investments and continue to make investments in our technology platform for items that you referred to, things like repo, things like improving our capacity. So if you take a look at our Slide 8, on in our deck, you can see that the day after the Brexit vote, we had the highest message traffic in our history, and it was -- it did not impact our speed whatsoever. So I think keeping our platform robust and keeping our platform improving the technology, improving the functionality, so that's the items that we'll be investing in the second half of the year as we continue to trend.

componenttext: Sorry, I came on late, so I apologize in advance if this was asked already. But I want to just touch base on Brexit for a minute. componenttext: There is opportunities. As you know, Europe is a very large part of our franchise on a global basis. The short answer to your question is, yes, there are. And yes, yes, we -- there are opportunities and we are in full engagement mode with our client base regarding deep, deeper participation and into our marketplace and some of the opportunities that present themselves that fit very nicely once we are seeing to be changing or evolving client demand and client needs. And so one of the things we referred to in the earnings call, in my formal remarks, was precisely that opportunity that lays ahead of us. So Derek, Sean, Bryan and their respective staffs are talking very intently to our clients and to understand what their needs are. And as you point out, the certainty of U.S. regulation is a very large driver there, too.

componenttext: Thank you for joining us today. The entire team at CME is focused on driving the top line for the future and operating the business as efficiently as possible. componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the CME Group Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. I would like to turn the conference over to John Peschier. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us this morning. Gill and John will spend a few minutes discussing the results, and then we will open up the call for your questions. Terry, Bryan, Derek and Sean are on the call as well and will participate in the Q&A session.Befo
componenttext:
Thank you for joining us this morning. Gill and John will spend a few minutes discussing the results, and then we will open up the call for your questions. Terry, Bryan, Derek and Sean are on the call as well and will participate in the Q&A session.
Before they begin, I'll read the safe harbor language. Statements made on this call and in the slides on our website that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. These statements are not guarantees of future performance and involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual outcomes and results may differ materially from what is expressed or implied in any forward-looking statements. More detailed information about factors that may affect our performance may be found in our filings with the SEC, which are available on our website.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Gill.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mr. Peschier, and thank you all for joining us. It is another solid quarter for us. Average daily volume in Q2 rose by 13%, the same growth rate as our record first quarter.We had double-digit growth again from each of our buy-side client gro
componenttext:
Thank you, Mr. Peschier, and thank you all for joining us. It is another solid quarter for us. Average daily volume in Q2 rose by 13%, the same growth rate as our record first quarter.
We had double-digit growth again from each of our buy-side client groups, including asset managers, hedge funds, proprietary trading firms, corporates and retail. Despite the recent slowdown and volatility post-Brexit as measured by the VIX, we are tracking up 10% compared with last July.
We were pleased to set an open interest record in the second quarter of over 116 million contracts, and we are near peaks in our large open interest holders data in several product areas. This morning, I will start with our secular drivers, and then I will shift to a few product highlights. We have consistently expanded our global participation in spite of the challenging macroenvironment. We saw robust electronic trading activity outside of the U.S. with Asia up 21% versus Q2 last year, Latin America rose 16% and Europe rose 12%. Following the Brexit announcement, we had significant activity from outside of the U.S. with 5.3 million contracts traded from Europe and 1.9 million contracts traded from Asia the day after.
In Q2, the electronic volume from outside of the U.S. is 24%. In July, that has jumped to 27%; and the day after Brexit, 29% of the activity was outside of the U.S.
In Europe, volumes in five of our product areas grew by more than 20% with the strongest growth in energy and equities with year-to-date ADV up 38% and 35%, respectively.
In Asia, future ADV and energy rose by more than 140%, and metals volumes jumped more than 80%. Latin America growth was also led by energy. In addition to the country of origin information that we shared with you, we also track electronic volume throughout the 24-hour trading day.
In Q2, volume during Asian hours grew by almost 40% from 260,000 contracts per day last year to 360,000 this quarter. During European hours, from 11:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m central time, volume rose from 750,000 per day to 1.1 million a day, up almost 45%.
Turning to our efforts in options. We remain a  leader relative to other global exchanges with Q2 options rising 15% and electronic options average daily volume rising 23% to 1.7 million contracts.
In Q2, the percentage of options that traded on Globex reached an all-time high of 57%, up from 51% in Q1. We saw the highest electronic percentage to date in interest rates, energy and metals. Agriculture options reached a record quarterly ADV of 345,000, up 26% from the prior year.
Lastly, in June, we had the highest month ever in total weekly options products with 495,000 contracts per day, up 57%.
Moving on to our commodities portfolio. We had a very impressive quarter with energy, ag and metals, each up more than 20% in revenue. We also set new records of large open interest holders in metals and ag, reaffirming that global customers continue to manage their commodities markets' risk exposures at CME Group. We track substitute products very closely, and we have outperformed peers in crude futures, crude options, natural gas futures, natural gas options, gold and copper so far in 2016.
Energy was particularly strong with Q2 average daily volume of 2.3 million contracts, and July has continued to be robust with volumes up 20%. In Q2, crude was up 38%, natural gas rose 17%, and refined products increased 18%.
The European and Asian activity in energy mentioned earlier highlights our extremely focused attention on our customers globally and the growing relevance of our product set.
Growth in energy options has been meaningful. WTI options volume rose more than 20% to more than 180,000 contracts per day, while natural gas options were up almost 20% as well.
Within energy options, we have grown from 49% electronic in Q1 to 53% in Q2 and up to 57% so far this month.
Energy ADV in the second quarter was the second highest quarter ever behind the record first quarter this year.
Our metals business during the quarter was phenomenal. Volume was up 41% and transaction revenues rose 35%. Our precious metals average daily volume was up 43%, while copper rose 33% versus a year ago. Options activity was strong, up 32% compared to last year. Metals had a second best quarter ever, and we had outperformed substitute products at other exchanges by a significant amount. We were also able to achieve multiple all-time open interest records in copper as well as set the all-time records for large open interest holders in both gold and silver in July.
Last but not least, our agriculture business had its highest volume quarter in our history. Ag options rose 26% and futures were up 22%. Soybeans led the way, up 49%, while corn, soybean meal and Hard Red Winter Wheat each grew more than 20%. It is worth noting that they are increasing expectations of the likelihood of La Nina. We would expect that to impact both agricultural volumes as well as benefiting our natural gas markets.
Turning to financial products and starting with interest rates, average daily volume in Q2 was up 3% and year-to-date we are up 7%.
Within Eurodollar options, volume increased 28% during the second quarter. Recently, we have had progress developing liquidity and trading on the screen with the electronic percentage increasing from 23% to 25% from Q1 to Q2. Also, the electronic volume during the U.S. hours from the pits that are open continues to increase significantly. Fed fund futures continued to be robust. As we have seen, Fed expectations move around before, during and after the Brexit vote.
Fed funds futures averaged more than 142,000 contracts per day in Q2, up almost 140%. In addition, we spoke about the successful launch of the Ultra 10-Year product last quarter, and volume has jumped from 35,000 contracts per day to over 60,000 and July is tracking at that same level.
We launched options clearing in the second quarter with 5 approved clearing members, and we'll now cleared dealer-to-dealer and customer trades. In addition to Swaptions, our recently launched Brazilian real IRS clearing offering began scaling in June and we now have 24 participants who have cleared the product thus far.
We continue to outperform other related markets indicating the proportion of activities shifting to our interest rate futures and options. For example, while we are up 7% year-to-date in interest rate volumes, global dealer-to-clients swap trading volumes were down 10% in the dollar fix to floating market. We continued to capture market share in treasuries, which we talked about before as cash treasuries are down 5%, while our treasury futures are flat. Our open interest in rates continues to hit record elevated levels above $63 million contracts in March and June, while rate related open interest at most of our exchanges peaked several years ago.
Turning to equities. ADV was up 25% in Q2 to almost 3 million contracts. And as I mentioned, we have had great participation from clients around the world. We had solid activity in equity options, which grew 24% during the quarter. We were particularly pleased with the record of more than 440,000 equity options that traded post-Brexit before the U.S. stock market even opened. 
In addition, last week, we announced the launch of S&P 500 Total Return Index futures and the S&P 500 Carry Adjusted Total Return Index futures. These innovative products are intended to mimic the economics of a total return swap in futures form, allowing swap dealers and their end clients to avoid higher costs as a result of new swap margin rules that are expected on September 1.
This is another example of CME Group's ongoing commitment to meet the changing needs of our clients in an evolving global marketplace. The S&P 500 Total Return Index futures will be available to trade by BTIC, which is Basis Trade Index at Close and will further expand the U.S. major index BTIC offering, which traded a record $32 billion in notional value during Q2. 
Lastly, our FX business was down 7% in Q2 as trading environment was challenging pre-Brexit. So far this year, we have outperformed the 2 largest FX platforms in terms of trading activity versus last year. Our FX markets performed very well during the post-Brexit day, but the markets were active and we had record British pound activity with more than 500,000 contracts traded that day.
Speaking of Brexit, we were very busy after the results came in, particularly during the pre-U.S. hours. We had a record 350 million messages to process. And as the slide in our presentation shows, we handled it without any issues. This is a tribute to our hard-working colleagues, who are ready to handle strong activity when volatility spiked.
We have had a tremendous opportunity during the last few months to deeply engage with our global clients as markets growth continued to evolve with uncertainty post-Brexit and also the upcoming implementation of margin for uncleared swaps. We have been talking to folks about the greater regulatory certainty under U.S. regulation. And based on the results again this quarter, it is clear customers at every continent are comfortable with the U.S. regime. This was further solidified with recognition and permanent QCCP status in Europe that we received in June.
The next potential catalyst for increased exchange trading and swaps clearing is in about 5 weeks when the first phase begins in the interdealer market requiring daily initial margin in variation region margin to be exchanged on a bilateral common noncentrally cleared portfolios in the U.S..
There will be a 10-day margin period of risk that will be put in place for uncleared swaps, and there will be less netting available compared to the 5-day period for cleared swaps and generally 1 to 2 days for futures and options.
Based on many client discussions, we are accelerating internal product development to try to create solutions that can provide relief for participants, including intermediaries and end clients. I mentioned the S&P 500 Total Return Index futures launched prior to September 1. Within our interest rate and FX areas, we are examining multiple new product ideas and looking at product construction. Within FX, opportunities we are working on include clearing for OTC FX options and nondeliverable forwards. 
In addition, within rates, we believe this could be a catalyst for our Swaptions business, and they're getting inbound calls from customers about other ideas. Lastly, I mentioned repo clearing last quarter, and we continued to make significant progress on the operational side in terms of technology and clearing, and we are working closely with large banks, asset managers and hedge funds. In addition, we are planning to be operationally prepared to launch fairly soon after regulatory approval.
In summary, we continue to expand our global footprint and product offerings to create opportunities for our clients and our shareholders. We have worked hard to position the company for success in the world that needs transparent, clear solutions for risk management now more than ever. 
With that, I'm going to turn the call over to John to discuss the financials. Thank you.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gill, and good morning, everyone. Our team has been intensely focused on driving global revenue growth, operating our business as efficiently as possible and returning excess capital to our shareholders in a consistent manner.As Gill mentione
componenttext:
Thank you, Gill, and good morning, everyone. Our team has been intensely focused on driving global revenue growth, operating our business as efficiently as possible and returning excess capital to our shareholders in a consistent manner.
As Gill mentioned, we had another excellent quarter. Total revenue was up 11% compared to a very strong quarter in Q2 last year with 4 of our 6 product areas delivering more than 20% revenue growth. Our adjusted expenses, excluding license fees were flat with the second quarter of last year, so almost all of the incremental revenue dropped to the operating income line. Our adjusted operating margin expanded by 3 percentage points from a year ago and adjusted EPS was up more than 15% for the second quarter in a row.
This quarter, we removed amortization from our adjusted results, and we provided a summary of the impact on prior quarters both in our earnings presentation deck, as well as in the income statement trend file we posted on our website. This change puts the reporting of our adjusted results in line with our U.S. exchange peers.
Our rate per contract for the second quarter was $0.782, up from $0.756 in Q1 due primarily to a positive shift in product mix, which was slightly offset by the member --  nonmember mix.
Market data revenue was $103 million, up slightly from the prior quarter. 
Moving to expenses. Excluding license fees and adjustments, our total expense was $270 million, exactly where we were in Q2 2015, which I am pleased to report along with the solid top line growth. For the first half of the year, on new spaces, we were at $534 million, up about 1/2 of 1%. For the second half, I would expect expenses to be about $548 million. The increase from the first half is based on our heavier spend on customer-related activity in Q4 and the acceleration of product development, which Gill alluded to. We will be lower than our initial guidance at the beginning of the year, which included amortization and excluded license fees by $4 million.
Instead of being up 1%, we are guiding to 0.5% increase on that basis. We ended the quarter with approximately 2,640 employees, up 40 from last quarter, driven primarily by entry-level hires and hires in lower cost locations.
Our competition ratio from Q2 came in at 14.5% and is down from 17% in Q2 last year. Looking at the nonoperating income and expense line, our ownership in S&P Dow Jones joint venture drove more than $27 million in net earnings from unconsolidated subsidiaries, up slightly from Q1. 
Turning to investment income. We received $2.6 million in dividends from BB&F. In addition, our investment returns generated through reinvestment of cash performance bonds and guaranteed funds contributions during Q2, decreased sequentially to $5.2 million from $7 million in Q1.
This is a result of lower average daily investment balances from the prior quarter and our net return during Q2 was 9 basis points. While we have been approved to establish an account with the Fed for house cash, it is not live yet, and we continue to work through the operational details.
Turning to taxes. For the quarter, we ended at an adjusted 36.5%, which is where we guided. And now to the balance sheet. At the end of the second quarter, we had $1.34 billion in cash, restricted cash and marketable securities. During the second quarter, capital expenditures net of leasehold improvement allowances were $20 million, as we continue to leverage more software and infrastructure as a service, which is included in expense.
We originally guided to $115 million to $120 million for the year. I'm going to reduce that by $15 million to $100 million to $105 million based on efficiency efforts and timing.
One final item I want to outline today is  a new program we have available for equity members. These firms are required to hold shares of CME Group Class A common stock in addition to seats to receive equity membership privileges.
Under the terms of the program, participants may substitute the assignment of the required shares by paying us a monthly subscription. Currently, there are 370 institutions that are required to hold CME Group Class A common shares as part of their equity membership.
A typical equity member is required to hold 20,000 shares per exchange in addition to seats. For most of the equity members, the subscription rate will be $7500 per month per exchange. This will provide choice for the firms and potentially allow them to free up capital to deploy in other ways. Each of the 370 firms will have full discretion on whether or not to participate in the program. The timing under evaluation and decision to participate is expected to lead to an orderly share release over time and should be easily absorbed by the market. As it is unclear on the participation level, we will update you next quarter on the uptake.
At a 50% participation level, we would generate an estimated $20 million of incremental annual revenue and up to $40 million if all equity members switch to monthly subscription. 
In summary, I am very pleased with the hard work this quarter across the entire business. Our secular growth drivers continue to deliver results with or without volatility. Our efficiency on expenses has been excellent, and since the first of the year, we have returned $1.4 billion in dividends. With that, we'd like to open up the call for your questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

componenttext: It's Kim. The operational details are not very interesting, actually. We're working with the Fed on the setup for the account. I think we would anticipate that we would have the account active, both for the end of this year probably in like a 2, 3 months timeframe. And right now, it's available for house accounts only, and so that would be the amount of cash that we would have available to invest in it potentially.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I've been called, Ron, recently as well. I guess -- thanks, Gill, for the -- you did an extensive product volume and even geographic review of how you're doing, how well you're doing. I guess, my question is, do you guys target -- what new products can ac
componenttext: I've been called, Ron, recently as well. I guess -- thanks, Gill, for the -- you did an extensive product volume and even geographic review of how you're doing, how well you're doing. I guess, my question is, do you guys target -- what new products can actually impact your volume or your revenue in 1 year's timeframe? If you assume -- I know this isn't reality, but if you assume a similar environment, what do you try to get -- expect to get from these new products as a company as an exchange? And then I guess, the follow-up would be which of the big ones -- which products are most impactful to that?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rich, I'll start and then I'll ask both Derek and Sean to comment if they want to. I think when you talk about product innovation here, you are always facing the uncertainty of whether it will be successful or not. What we have started doing, particu
componenttext: Yes, Rich, I'll start and then I'll ask both Derek and Sean to comment if they want to. I think when you talk about product innovation here, you are always facing the uncertainty of whether it will be successful or not. What we have started doing, particularly in the last 5 to 7 years we've had a comprehensive plan and part of that planning is talking to clients on a very broad basis. So in previous calls, I've spoken to you about the number of folks that tune into seminars that we put on and that's an indication to us. And 1 example is the Ultra 10-year bond that we launched and the enthusiasm behind the bond and the corresponding volume that we got since launch has been great. And so we've got a pipeline on both the commodity side and the financial side, and our guys are pretty excited about some of the prospects there. So I will turn it over to Sean to comment on some of those things and then Mr.  Sammann can talk about others.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In terms of the bottom line on these products, if you look at the TN as Gill mentioned, we were doing 60,000 contracts a day. So you can look at our rates RPC, which is publicly available, and you can see that we're running currently at several mill
componenttext: Sure. In terms of the bottom line on these products, if you look at the TN as Gill mentioned, we were doing 60,000 contracts a day. So you can look at our rates RPC, which is publicly available, and you can see that we're running currently at several million dollars a year in terms of revenues, in terms of the run rate. If you look at Mexican pesos and our interest rate swaps clearing business, we now offer 19 currencies relative to the large competitor offering 17 currencies. So we got 2 now unique value propositions in terms of currencies, both the Mexican peso and the Brazilian real. In terms of the Mexican peso, we have MXN 1.5 million a month is our current run rate. So while it is a small currency, it's actually having a significant impact on that business. If you look at the Brazilian reai, as Gill mentioned on the call, we're hitting a critical mass in the month of June. To put in perspective, we launched -- it takes time for the new products to gain traction relative to building a critical mass of participants. In the month of June, we had a $5 billion equivalent. Total volume cleared in the month of July -- sorry, that was in the month of May. Excuse me, $5 billion in the month of May. In the month of June, we had $35 billion. The Brazilian real against unique value proposition relative to our largest competitor, it is a larger currency than Mexican peso, so we do expect eventually to make more in the Brazilian real than we are currently making in the Mexican peso. We had big success in our equity products that were launched in November of last year. The dividend futures, which we've spoken about are running about 1,000 day. The bigger and more exciting thing relative to future growth is we've got over 50,000 contracts in open interest. In terms of BTIC, we're trading that's on the S&P 500 in particular. We're trading 5,000 contracts a day. If you look at new products, we hope that they drive typically 3-or-so percent of our top line growth. We have other new products that we're launching with Swaptions. As I said, it takes a while to build a critical mass. With the Brazilian real, it took us from August of last year until June of this year to start hitting a critical mass. We do expect with U.S. dollar swaptions to hit a critical mass hopefully in the fourth quarter and to begin to see significant growth starting then. So we see strong growth across each of our product areas with top line of 3% plus. Derek, do you want to jump in?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's from a product launch perspective, which we're trying to look at this in terms of your client need market structure shift and what is changing the environment that provides an opportunity for us to provide a service that is not offered b
componenttext: Yes, I think it's from a product launch perspective, which we're trying to look at this in terms of your client need market structure shift and what is changing the environment that provides an opportunity for us to provide a service that is not offered by someone out there. And that's the way to think about product developments and opportunities is where there are global benchmarks that might be in this repair or broken benchmarks. Clients not able to manage a risk the way they could. Those are market entry opportunities for us. For example, our move into aluminum 18 months ago was a result of customers not being able to access their fiscal aluminum get it out of their warehouse. So the growth in market share and revenue generation on our copper business has been largely helped by our entering the aluminum market. In fact, MillerCoors announced just last month that they're going to be shifting their price benchmark for the North American aluminum procurement to a CME-based product that we launched 18 months ago. Looking forward, the other area of product opportunity and development, is where we can add products to our overall portfolio. So as Gill mentioned, we've hit record revenue generation in our agriculture products business. We announced last month that we'll be launching our European wheat contracts on September 12 of this year and that fills out what is already a globally utilized contract with the products that addresses some of the shortcomings in the current products. So great opportunities there and we're into our portfolio of services, making it easier from a capital perspective and operational asset perspective for our customers to manage all the risk at CME Group. That's been our focal point for product development.

componenttext: Just kind of curious, I mean, obviously, we saw some great strength in agricultural metals this quarter. And I think, Gill, alluded to some of the strength that was probably driven by weather. I was trying to also kind of think about moving forward where the growth is like? Does it come from here, from current levels? I mean, there's been some articles about Chinese retail investors getting involved in metals futures trading, agriculture futures trading. I'm just [indiscernible] wondering if there's any sense for what is sustainable moving forward? What's been cyclical? And what gives you confidence that maybe you can grow from current levels?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As you pointed out, there is a regional growth story here, particularly outside of the U.S. And on the commodities front, it's particularly strong coming from Asia in both the energy and med -- metals front. Mr. Sammann, do you want to add some deta
componenttext: Sure. As you pointed out, there is a regional growth story here, particularly outside of the U.S. And on the commodities front, it's particularly strong coming from Asia in both the energy and med -- metals front. Mr. Sammann, do you want to add some detail there?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're particularly excited about the numbers we've been sharing with you guys about the commodities footprint that we're going in Asia. If you look at the energy revenues we generated year-to-date, energy revenues is now representing almost 3
componenttext: Yes, I think we're particularly excited about the numbers we've been sharing with you guys about the commodities footprint that we're going in Asia. If you look at the energy revenues we generated year-to-date, energy revenues is now representing almost 35% of the total revenues we're generating out of China and greater China as a whole. Our business in greater China, mean Hong Kong, China and Taiwan is up 227%. The metals business, specifically, is our second biggest revenue source in the same region and that's up 61%. So the opportunities that we've got when we own the COMEX benchmarks from the metal side, our ability to position ourselves as a global benchmarks in region with the sales efforts that Brian and his team has been putting forth in region to make sure that we're accessing a customer base with global liquidity by time zone as well, that's how we see the opportunity continue to build into that community. I would also like to add that if you look at the importance of the commercial customers who are commodities complex as a whole, we continued to focus on them being is the primary driver of our access, because as you address those end-user customer needs, that brings the other market participants, the profit to banks, the others that want to be where the end-user customers are. So when you look at the revenue growth of the franchise as a whole, the record level of large open interest [indiscernible]  record level open interest itself  layered on top of the China growth, tells a story of globalized participation in our markets and globalizing access to those global participant based on the commercial side.

Just wanted to get a sense of if there's anything from a timing standpoint or maybe from the CapEx standpoint to seem a little bit less than expected?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. No, it's not unusual for our cash balance to grow slower in Q2. The primary reason is that we have 2 tax payments in the second quarter, and for this quarter, it was $416 million. And we also have our regular dividend of $202 million that happ
componenttext: Sure, Mike. No, it's not unusual for our cash balance to grow slower in Q2. The primary reason is that we have 2 tax payments in the second quarter, and for this quarter, it was $416 million. And we also have our regular dividend of $202 million that happened this quarter. So it's not unusual for Q2 to be a slower quarter in terms of cash build. So we have tremendous leverage in our business model and we've been able to return $1.4 billion in dividends year-to-date. So obviously, that is a cash impact.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Take the market data. It's Bryan. First of all, we've been monitoring closely our subscriber base since we implemented the full fare back in January, and we're pleased to see we're not seeing any [indiscernible] reductions or consolidations in that regard
componenttext: Take the market data. It's Bryan. First of all, we've been monitoring closely our subscriber base since we implemented the full fare back in January, and we're pleased to see we're not seeing any [indiscernible] reductions or consolidations in that regard. With that in mind, we've really been focused on developing new opportunities for revenue. One of the areas that we have an increased emphasis on is our development of derived data, and it's representing a very nice revenue stream for us. So you can expect to see more activities on that end. While we haven't announced any type of price increase in 2017, we will be expecting an increase that will impact certain segments and offerings associated with our market data.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Bryan, in terms of the use obstruction plan, the purpose of the program is to provide our members flexibility. So the members either can hold our shares or they can free up those shares and pay us a subscription fee. So this gives our members a choice
componenttext: So Bryan, in terms of the use obstruction plan, the purpose of the program is to provide our members flexibility. So the members either can hold our shares or they can free up those shares and pay us a subscription fee. So this gives our members a choice and how to deploy their capital. Also, it may make it easier for potential new members, especially those international members whom we find holding CME shares prohibitive. So this is good for our current members, it's good for our potential new members and it's good for CME, because we will be generating recurring revenue from that payment. And it's likely going to show up in our other revenue line, not necessarily in the market data line, and obviously, this is all incremental to our bottom line.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: And the range is $20 million to $40 million based on your estimates?

componenttext: Well, yes, assuming a 50% take up, it's about $20 million. If all members chose to do this program, it will be $40 million. We don't have clear line of sight in terms of what the uptick will be, so we'll be able to update you next quarter as it rolls out.

componenttext: I guess,  I'm going to back that last question just for market data. I mean, you talked to some of the derived data, I think. I was just curious,  how interested that you guys are to what extent you've kind of explored adding to the business inorganically, just additional analytics or other solutions like some of your peers kind of have? Just maybe broaden or maybe improve the overall value add of that offering?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We certainly are open to looking at any opportunities that can augment or enhance the strong and robust business that we have with respect to market data. As I've indicated, there are tools that we have at our disposal right now as we're developing new pr
componenttext: We certainly are open to looking at any opportunities that can augment or enhance the strong and robust business that we have with respect to market data. As I've indicated, there are tools that we have at our disposal right now as we're developing new products internally that we really haven't leveraged to the degree that we believe that we can. Part of that is the derived data space and developing new products as a result of that. So we're certainly happy to look at any opportunities that do augment the great robust business that we have today.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just to add to that, one thing to remember is that we do have a data investment in our JV with S&P. So that's an area that is also looking to grow, and we'll be looking at nonorganic opportunities as well. So we've not only participating directly thr
componenttext: Yes. Just to add to that, one thing to remember is that we do have a data investment in our JV with S&P. So that's an area that is also looking to grow, and we'll be looking at nonorganic opportunities as well. So we've not only participating directly through, as Bryan indicated our data business here, but we'll also be participating with our S&P partners with joint venture.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
