componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Alex Kramm with UBS.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Probably for Gill, but maybe for some of the others, too. You mentioned, Gill, the uncleared margin rules that came in September. Can you elaborate a little bit in terms of the discussions and what you've seen from clients in terms of -- I hear you on NDS
componenttext: Probably for Gill, but maybe for some of the others, too. You mentioned, Gill, the uncleared margin rules that came in September. Can you elaborate a little bit in terms of the discussions and what you've seen from clients in terms of -- I hear you on NDS, but I think, historically, you've also talked about maybe uncleared margin rules would drive more uptick in futures. And then just lastly, who's shifting so far? What kind of customers? Because I think the bigger group of clients coming on in March, so just curious if you think that's going to be a bigger bump and more dramatic change when those rules come in.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Alex. This is Sean jumping in. On the increased margin rules, September 1 was the date U.S., Japan and Canada implemented them. The CFTC had a no action relief until October 3. The biggest impact, according to the reports, are in rates and foreign e
componenttext: Sure, Alex. This is Sean jumping in. On the increased margin rules, September 1 was the date U.S., Japan and Canada implemented them. The CFTC had a no action relief until October 3. The biggest impact, according to the reports, are in rates and foreign exchange. In terms of rates, the biggest new offering that we have out there that we think could help relieve some of the challenges that the market faces are swaptions clearing. On swaptions clearings, we currently have 7 clearing members who have been approved by the Risk Committee, 2 new clearing members in the last couple of months. And we were excited that that's a great place to relieve a lot of the uncleared marginal requirements in the rates area. Then if you look at the FX market, as you said, the NDF market, we have an NDF marked offering out here. We also clear our cash settle forwards. But in addition to that, we've began working very hard on OTC FX options clearing. And we believe the combination of all of those products together will be very attractive to market participants. We're working very closely with a set of marketing participants on that. In terms of equities, equities, according to BIS reports, kind of third after those of classes in terms of the impacts on the marketplace. We launched on our August, late August, a total return S&P 500 futures that would nearly replicate the economics of our total return swaps, so the OTC equity swaps market. With the no actual relief until October 3, we didn't see any trades in that until the week of October 3rd, but that week immediately with several participants trade in that first week, about 3,500 contracts. So you're talking about $3.5 billion approximately, and they traded in blocks of about $500 million each. So you have very large participants testing the pipes relative to the equity futures, the equity total return futures. In terms of the next 4 years, it's only the top 20 or 21[ph] institutions in the world that are affected today. Over the next 4 years, the expectation is that will become over 2,000 firms, so we do expect to relative to our focus on it, relative to new products and services that we're offering, that will -- there will be a lot of pain out there that we can help relieve with the new cleared products, as well as the new -- as well as for futures products.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Patrick O'Shaughnessy with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Patrick O'Shaughnessy with Raymond James.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the dealers keep bringing up the topic of the skin in the game and the clearinghouses and how much capital that CME puts up in terms of the waterfall. What are your current views in terms of maybe additional money that you'll need to put into clearing
componenttext: So the dealers keep bringing up the topic of the skin in the game and the clearinghouses and how much capital that CME puts up in terms of the waterfall. What are your current views in terms of maybe additional money that you'll need to put into clearing houses? And what's sort of leverage does the dealers have to try to impact your behavior there?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure. And I'll ask Kim to join in. I'm not sure about the leverage that the deals would actually have, but they are actually focused on the skin in the game issue itself. As you may or may not know, we pioneered the concept in the late 60s, and we
componenttext: I'm not sure. And I'll ask Kim to join in. I'm not sure about the leverage that the deals would actually have, but they are actually focused on the skin in the game issue itself. As you may or may not know, we pioneered the concept in the late 60s, and we're comfortable with skin and the game. We think it's necessary to have. But we're also, very, very much in tune with respect to the moral hazard issue here. And if you look at our skin in the game and what the amount is, there are tons of views out there, all the ad hoc views with respect to what that amount should actually be. From our perspective, at the $500 million or so level that we have across the board, it's about the average contribution of each of those firms, all right? And we have affirmatively said that we strongly believe that those that bring risks should be the ones that fund the guarantee fund. We manage the risk that they bring, and we are ultra comfortable with the levels that we have. Anything to add, Kim?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just expand a little bit on the moral hazard point. I mean I agree with Gill that we are very big believers in skin of the game from the clearing house. The clearing house needs the alignment of incentives with the clearing member. But the clearin
componenttext: I would just expand a little bit on the moral hazard point. I mean I agree with Gill that we are very big believers in skin of the game from the clearing house. The clearing house needs the alignment of incentives with the clearing member. But the clearing members are very important participants in any kind of default management situation. And the mutualization of risks across clearing mechanisms is part of the reason why clearinghouse mechanism works so effectively. And turning too much of that to the contribution of the CCP upfront could change the dynamics of the risk mechanisms that support a good default management. So the moral hazard is very real, and it shows up in multiple ways in the process.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: So just thinking through the dividend policy, and I guess the trade-off between increase in fee variable, the increase in your occurring dividend versus a bigger specialist we're thinking out over the next year or so, just curious to get your update on that.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We feel very strongly that we got a very good dividend policy between the regular dividend and the annual variable dividend. As you saw this year, we adjusted our regular dividend, up 20% to create more of a balance between the annual variable and the reg
componenttext: We feel very strongly that we got a very good dividend policy between the regular dividend and the annual variable dividend. As you saw this year, we adjusted our regular dividend, up 20% to create more of a balance between the annual variable and the regular dividend. So we are very committed to the policy. And as we mentioned in the prepared remarks, there'll be some positive increases in terms of the amount of cash going into the fourth quarter related to our sale down of our stake in BM&F. So that freed up about $150 million in cash that can be used when determining the annual variable dividend.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was actually just thinking that, is the increase in the quarterly something we should expect every year from you guys, or was the event this year kind of one-time?
componenttext: I was actually just thinking that, is the increase in the quarterly something we should expect every year from you guys, or was the event this year kind of one-time?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really limited. It's a board decision, but if you take a look at our past, we've had a policy of consistently increasing our regular dividend. But it's really a board decision, and it's something that we'll analyzing in the fourth quarter, along with
componenttext: It's really limited. It's a board decision, but if you take a look at our past, we've had a policy of consistently increasing our regular dividend. But it's really a board decision, and it's something that we'll analyzing in the fourth quarter, along with the annual variable dividend level.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Kyle Voigt with KBW.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Kyle Voigt with KBW.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the energy slide comparing your WTI versus Isis Brandt contract. I think if we look at futures open interest specifically, we aren't seeing necessarily the same shift. So can you help us understand the variance there between open interest and ADV?
componenttext: Just on the energy slide comparing your WTI versus Isis Brandt contract. I think if we look at futures open interest specifically, we aren't seeing necessarily the same shift. So can you help us understand the variance there between open interest and ADV? And I guess what is driving the increased volume and activity rates in your WTI contract?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Kyle, it's Derek, I'll answer your question. We're actually very excited about the growth rates that we've been able to unlock in our energy complex. And it's a number of factors that we are controlling for in terms of our ability to both roll out pr
componenttext: Yes. Kyle, it's Derek, I'll answer your question. We're actually very excited about the growth rates that we've been able to unlock in our energy complex. And it's a number of factors that we are controlling for in terms of our ability to both roll out product, acquire new customers, position our benchmark product, and what is a market that is shifting structurally in favor of our benchmark products that whether you look at the -- lifting the export ban in crude back in December of 2015, creating a water balloon product that is WTI, we now have a product that the market is increasingly adopting as a global benchmark. As Gill referenced in his earlier comments at the top of the call, our growth in Asia, particularly in our energies franchise, is up in excess of 100%. So adoption and participation in our markets globally is increasing as we're leveraging. Bryan and the teams on the ground in here and in Asia to go access and bring new customers on board. And when you actually think about the energies complex as a whole, we're thinking about well beyond just the crude story. We're talking about nat gas as well. So I we talk about the overall franchise on Slide 9 of the deck that we sent to you guys, in the same structural shifts we talked about that are beneficial to our crude business favoring WTI over brent, we're also seeing some reconnecting of the global nat gas market. On Slide 9, on the right-hand side, we've got a graph of what we're showing as a reconnecting of the prices of U.S. nat gas, really driven by our physical Henry hub products between the prices both in Asia and Germany. When you look at the market share that we've grown to, we are now 76% market share of the global Henry Hub futures market, and that's up from 73% in 2015 and 68% in 2014. So we are excited about, as markets converge, the role that the Henry Hub futures complex, the physical part we launched will play as a benchmark product pricing in the global nat gas market as those prices disconnect from the crude market and reconnect globally. Also, the open interest levels, over the course of this year, we've reached not only record levels for open interest in nat gas, but we're hovering right at all-time hires in our large open interest holders on the futures side. And on the options, as we talked about previously, record levels of electronification and nat gas options and continued growth our nat gas options business level over 30% this year.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just staying on the energy theme, can you comment, Derek, about your NASDAQ kind of FX effort, whether that's actually enhancing your volumes, given the arbitrage between markets. And if that program is expanded over time, is there a net benefit for you,
componenttext: Just staying on the energy theme, can you comment, Derek, about your NASDAQ kind of FX effort, whether that's actually enhancing your volumes, given the arbitrage between markets. And if that program is expanded over time, is there a net benefit for you, or do you see that actually eventually being sort of a headwind on the incumbents market shares?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at the progress that we've made relative to the business that we developed, we've got a nice problem. We've got a market that's up over 30%. In September volume-wise, as I mentioned, the market share increase in nat[ph] 70% on the futures si
componenttext: When you look at the progress that we've made relative to the business that we developed, we've got a nice problem. We've got a market that's up over 30%. In September volume-wise, as I mentioned, the market share increase in nat[ph] 70% on the futures side. Our market share relative of the nat gas options is still around 64% or 65%. But what we've really done is we've focused on electronifying the nat gas options business. So when you look at what the other offerings are out there, this is a market that's typically been brokered, and we're the ones that have gone from less than 10% of electronic and nat gas options to a record of over 40%, as Gill mentioned at the top of the call. And as you've seen us do across products over time, when you focus on functionality and electronic access to your options market, bringing people to the transparent central order book, we tend to see the velocity transactions increase, and more importantly, can access our global customer base. That's really hard to do in the block market. So we're excited about the progress we've made, the harsh of the interest or cardholder record levels that we're touching on is really a reflection of the increased global adoption of our products set, so we're excited about the multiple records we've hit in nat gas options, ADV, single day record, large open interest holders, as well as the deferred month liquidity that we have built and focused on over the last 12 months as well. Our open interest in months 6 through 12 is at 36%, as we're focusing on the commercial end-user customers to bring them into our market, and those are the physical users that are using our products.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add to that, particularly out of Asia, which has been a bit of a struggle in the past in terms of the adoption of our energy products. The leader in terms of growth throughout Greater China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, as well as within Korea, is unqu
componenttext: I would just add to that, particularly out of Asia, which has been a bit of a struggle in the past in terms of the adoption of our energy products. The leader in terms of growth throughout Greater China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, as well as within Korea, is unquestionably been in the energy. Those that had traditionally favored the alternative to our WTI have been increasingly adopting our crude. And they've been very noticeably active in the natural gas and very pleased to see the greater transparency associated with that. So we're going to continue driving that progress within those regions. The same holds true for within greater Europe.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: I just want to get your take on the paper on CCP, and what global regulators are doing in respect to the systemic risks of CCP. So where do you expect regulation to go if anywhere at all?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vincent, this is Gill. I'll answer, then I will ask Kim to add if she has anything to add. I think the SSB, like all the other regulators, are concerned about CCP resiliency, just as and the CFTC is. And I think the authorities such as the CFTC are famili
componenttext: Vincent, this is Gill. I'll answer, then I will ask Kim to add if she has anything to add. I think the SSB, like all the other regulators, are concerned about CCP resiliency, just as and the CFTC is. And I think the authorities such as the CFTC are familiar with CCP, is familiar with the risk that CCPs bring, and they're comfortable, I think, with the framework that they have been overseeing for decades. I think the FSB, which includes some of the central banks of the world that don't necessarily -- have not necessarily overseeing CCP's are coming to grips to what those means and they're looking at various and scenarios, and this is all part and parcel of the knock on effects of the crisis of 2008. On our part, we are working very hard to educate to the extent that we can and also contribute to the debate to the extent that we are allowed to.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would just add a couple of things. Gill mentioned the kind of varying perspectives of different regulators. And one of the things -- a part of our advocacy is to help educate regulators that our newer to the regulation of clearing houses or CCPs. B
componenttext: Yes. I would just add a couple of things. Gill mentioned the kind of varying perspectives of different regulators. And one of the things -- a part of our advocacy is to help educate regulators that our newer to the regulation of clearing houses or CCPs. Because although the G20 and the regulation have pushed products into clearing mechanisms because clearing mechanisms worked in the crisis, the interesting thing is it now they are thinking about slightly changing the way clearing mechanisms need to work, so we want to make sure that clearing mechanisms maintain their effectiveness, and our advocacy is in that regard with respect to flexibility and crisis management and the ability to have strong risk management programs.

componenttext: Sure, this is John. I'll take it, and I'll ask Derek to comment specifically on the energy side. So within the equities, we had a higher proportion of member trading. And in energy, we had 2 factors. One is we had a larger proportion of member trading than last quarter, with member volumes up 19% and nonmembers up 15%. We also saw large increase in the use of our electronic natural gas options, which are lower pricing Trayport. And Derek, if you want to comment on what you're seeing in terms of options trading, that will be great. But before we do that, I'll just mention in terms of the advertising campaign, yes, it's geared towards more a retail and nonmembers. So with that, I'll hand it over to Derek on the options.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the nat gas side, as John mentioned, there is 2 things going on. #1, you've seen us build into sustainable growth and options markets by making sure that we can build those markets electronically, so we can market that liquidity globally. We phase
componenttext: Yes. On the nat gas side, as John mentioned, there is 2 things going on. #1, you've seen us build into sustainable growth and options markets by making sure that we can build those markets electronically, so we can market that liquidity globally. We phased the market structure in nat gas options a year ago, that was 95% broker, less than 5% traded on screen. So every time we shifted business is from a brokered market on to the screen. We've done that because our experience has shown that you create a sticky ecosystem of user participants by bringing them into the the order book. The downside of that is you end up getting up our block surcharge when we charge people an excess amount for dealing outside of the central order books. So it's been a very disciplined approach to move that business on screen, so we're finding that great deal of success, moving from less than 10% electronic to a record of 44% electronic earlier this year, I think in August and September, so it's a shift that we have anticipated, a shift we have undertaken in other markets as we globalize and electronify them and with the business up[ph] 31%, typically, you also start to move through volume tiers as well. So we consider this a first world problem relative to volumes growth and a disciplined move on to a central order book.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's Bryan. First of all, just to give you a little color, since the elimination of the electronic fee waivers been in full effect now for almost a year, where in all of our professional users are paying the full market data subscriber fee revenues,
componenttext: Yes. It's Bryan. First of all, just to give you a little color, since the elimination of the electronic fee waivers been in full effect now for almost a year, where in all of our professional users are paying the full market data subscriber fee revenues, and our subscribers remained stable. Now as we continued to advance our market data and IP growth opportunities, we've been performing a holistic assessment of our current program. And our assessment indicates that there are opportunities to extract additional value in revenues from our assets. So for example in 2017, we expect that the manner in which we charge for our core market data services will be modified to tailor our fees in a more targeted fashion. Our approach to charging trading and non-trading participants will be modified to address the global nature of this business and the various subscriber profiles that are consuming our data. So we believe our current pricing scheme does not fully capture the value Alex described to these different user segments. And just to give you a recent example of our targeted approach, I think I referenced at the last call that we are increasingly commercializing our derived and historical market data offerings. So with respect to derived data, there are increasing opportunities and there is a significant pipeline of demand for our data IP as the demand for the development of external product continues to increase. Now this clearly has been an area of revenue opportunity for us that we plan to drive greater growth, and it's been typically referenced in the past as core market data. So we will be separating that out increasingly and going after those opportunities on a derived basis. I think you also may be aware of our recent announcement of our new historical market data platform which we just recently introduced in conjunction with , so the usable data needs to be instantly accessible, and we've done that with our recent introduction of tech fault. Data users now can browse a data catalog, subscribe to the content needed and access it via the web interfaces and APIs almost instantaneously. So this is making data access easily, easy, and it's responsive to the global demand that we've been hearing, so we see more opportunities to extract more value in that regard. So that just gives you a taste of how we're really looking at the assets from the market data and IP perspective.

componenttext: Sure. I wouldn't say it wasn't as high as we expected. Also, we think it's beneficial for new members coming in, especially those from overseas, that we're holding CME stock, and having that amount of capital is prohibitive. So that takes time to work through the system. So in terms of the overall opportunity being about $40 million, we're at roughly 10% of that and it's only been out for just a couple of months. So for us, there's really nothing but upside for us.

componenttext: Yes. No, I agree with that. I think that when you look at our revenue coming out of our traditional retail, the way we measured it, basically next to nothing, and then putting in roughly a couple of hundred million dollars, I think, last year alone in coming from the retail side of the business, the upside is just extraordinary. We have I think somewhere in the neighborhood of 4% of the retail trade globally. And that if we could just double that, you can imagine what the revenue could do for this company. So we are taking a strong look at that. I think what's important is, here, we're not targeting the mom and pops on a street. When we call retail, we're talking about participants in the market every trading anywhere from 10 to 20 contracts a day already, and we're trying to harness that into the business. What I think is also fascinating is when you look at these discount retail equity brokers traditionally, they're starting to merge together the ones that offer futures. So that only bodes well for us to concentrate us more, people that are already offering us products.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Gill and John will spend a few minutes discussing the results, and then we'll open up the call for your questions. Terry, Bryan, Derek, Sean and Kim are on the call as well and may participate in the Q&A session.
Before they begin, I'll read the Safe Harbor language.
Statements made on this call and in the slides on our website that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements. These statements are not guarantees of future performance and involve risks, uncertainties and assumptions that are difficult to predict. Therefore, actual outcomes and results may differ materially from what is expressed or implied in any forward-looking statements. More detailed information about factors that may affect our performance may be found in our filings with the SEC, which are on our website. Also, on the last page of our earnings release, you will find a reconciliation between GAAP and non-GAAP measures.
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Gill.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mr. Peschier, and thank you all for joining us. We have consistently talked about our focus on globalizing our business, growing our industry-leading options and futures franchise, and solving challenges our customers face through a number of
componenttext:
Thank you, Mr. Peschier, and thank you all for joining us. 
We have consistently talked about our focus on globalizing our business, growing our industry-leading options and futures franchise, and solving challenges our customers face through a number of innovative product extensions. We made progress across all of these areas during the third quarter. 
Year-to-date, our volume is up 8%as is our transactions revenue, while earnings per share is up more than 10%. 
This morning, I will start with our secular drivers, then I will shift to a few product highlights. 
We have expanded our global footprint in spite of the challenging macro environment over the last 5 years. This quarter, we saw volume from Europe and Asia grew in the low single digits, while the U.S. activity was flat. Energy, in particular, stood out in Asia, Latin America and Europe. We also saw noticeable outperformance in FX during third quarter out of Europe, which is great to see. 
In addition to the country of origin information that we share with you, we also track electronic volume throughout the 24-hour trading day. In Q3, our volume during European trading hours increased by 20%, while activity during Asian hours was up 7%. The U.S. trading hours volume was down 1% because of tough comps vis-a-vis August of last year.
Turning to our efforts in our options franchise. We remain the leader relative to other global exchanges in terms of total options volume traded. During the third quarter, options reached the highest percentage on Globex to-date with more than 57% and September exceeded 60%. A critical focal point has been our continued investment in our functionality and technology to enable increased adoption of Globex execution for complex options spreads. We are pleased to confirm that we hit a record of 50% of all options spreads traded electronically in September, up from less than 20% in 2012. 
We continue to launch a number of exciting new product extensions. Our Ultra 10-Year treasury contract reached 73,000 contracts per day compared to 61,000 in Q2. Open interest continues to build, and the bid/offer spread is getting tighter. Building on the success of our weekly equity options that expire Friday each week, we launched weekly equity options with expirations about a month ago. Those are averaging 23,000 per day, and on 1 day, we traded 45,000. In continuing to tailor contracts to meet specific client needs, we launched S&P 500 Total Return Index Futures, and those have begun to trade in October. The other areas of focus related to the initial implementation of the uncleared margin requirements include some cleared FX products like NDFs and Options and potential new futures contracts, primarily in interest rate, equity and FX.
Moving on to our commodities portfolio. We had another strong quarter led by metals and energy, up 22% and 17%, respectively, year-over-year. In addition to strong volume growth, we continued to expand and diversify our global customer base across all of our commodities asset classes. We reach an all-time high this month in the number of large open interest holders in energy, while ags and metals large open interest holders have grown in the mid-single digits and remain near peak levels. This reaffirms that global customers continue to manage their commodities market risk exposure here at CME Group.
Our Metals business has been our fastest-growing segment this year with volumes up 29% to-date. Our precious metals business has performed extremely well despite a relatively flat volatility curve over the last year. With 74% of our Metal options now trading electronically, we have been able to expand our global customer base by delivering futures and options liquidity all the way through the Asian and European trading days. And in our industrial metals area, we continued to build on our success in our copper business, up 17% year-to-date compared to LME's copper business, which is down 7%. We also continued to grow our Copper Open Interest with September month-end open interest up 17% year-on-year. We are particularly proud to have expanded our Metals business with Asian clients by 45%, proving that we can effectively build business despite a challenging volatility environment.
Energy was particularly strong. In Q3, average daily volume of 2.3 million contracts, which is up 17%. In Q3, crude was up 20%. Natural gas rose 23%. And refined products increased 13%. Our natural gas options business has been a particular area of success with September volumes increasing 40%, driven by the significant growth in electronic volume.
Within natural gas options during the third quarter, we set records for monthly ADV, a single-day volume record as well as record levels of options trading on Globex at 44% for August, up from just 15% a year ago. We believe that there are structural shifts taking place in both the crude and natural gas markets, driven by the U.S. now becoming the swing producer in these markets, and we are well positioned to benefit from this shift. We have seen natural gas prices around the world begin to connect, which we believe bodes well for our physically settled Henry Hub contract over the long term. We see confirmation of global adoption of CME's benchmark Energy products in our global customer growth with Energy business in Asia up 104% in September.
Turning to financial products and starting with Interest Rates. Average daily volume in Q3 was up 2%, and year-to-date, we are up 5%. At the end of the quarter, our large open interest holders were very close to an all-time high. Our total open interest in rates at the end of September of about 55 million contracts was up 15% with Eurodollars up 17% and treasuries up 10%. Clearly, there is an increased focus on the front end of the yield curve and our Fedwatch tool is currently projecting a greater than 75% probability of a December move. Open interest in the first 4 quarterly Eurodollars futures contract reached 5.3 million contracts, which is a 4-year high.
Also, it is nice to see that our year-to-date fed funds futures average daily volume is up 70% to 134,000 contracts per day. Within treasuries, we have increased our cash treasury penetration market share metric to the highest level to-date and have increased by more than 2 percentage points since the beginning of the year to more than 80%. 
Over-the-counter swaps revenue approached $17 million in total during Q3, up from $13 million in Q2. We reached all-time volume records in our Latin America interest rate swaps in September with $10 billion per day in Mexican peso and $5 billion per day in Brazilian real. In addition, we have begun to charge for interest rate swap compression services and have compressed over $2.2 trillion since the fees have been implemented.
Turning to equities. Compared to the same quarter a year ago, S&P 500 volatility dropped substantially with a more normal summer quarter. Our volume was down 12% but compared favorably to the majority of the other equity-related volumes traded elsewhere. For example, we tracked the notional value of the E-mini S&P futures that we trade compared to these SPDR ETF. Last year, in the third quarter, the notional amount traded in our S&P futures was 7x that of the SPDR. This year in Q3, that ratio jumped to more than 10x higher. When you think about the all-in cost to trade based on a tight bid/offer spread and deep liquidity, we are considerably less expensive.
Lastly, within FX, we have seen decent year-over-year growth in volume in September and October, and we have outperformed other FX venues. Most importantly, within FX, we are pleased to see a new record number of large open interest holders in the most recent report in advance of the widely anticipated Fed meeting in December.
In summary, through the hard work of our staff, we continue to expand our global footprint and product offerings to create opportunities for our clients and our shareholders.
With that, I'm going to turn the call over to John to discuss the financials. Thank you.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gill, and good morning, everyone. Our team has been intensely focused on driving global revenue growth, operating our business as efficiently as possible and returning excess capital to our shareholders. Despite volatility in many asset class
componenttext:
Thank you, Gill, and good morning, everyone. 
Our team has been intensely focused on driving global revenue growth, operating our business as efficiently as possible and returning excess capital to our shareholders. Despite volatility in many asset classes being down significantly from Q3 last year, which included a particularly volatile August in 2015, we were able to come in basically flat in terms of revenue and EPS during the quarter. Volatility, by definition, does not come in smoothly when comparing periods, and I am pleased to say that our adjusted EPS through 3 quarters has grown 10% to $3.39 per share.
Our adjusted operating expenses, excluding license fees, were down 1% compared to the third quarter of last year. Our adjusted operating margin expanded slightly from a year ago to almost 66%.
Our rate per contract for the third quarter was $0.75, down from the prior quarter. This was primarily due to a member/nonmember shift in some of the asset classes that saw lower volatility, like equities. Also, within energy, we had a surge in our lower priced natural gas options, which created a negative venue shift.
Moving to expenses. Excluding license fees and adjustments, our total expense dropped 1% from the prior year to $257 million, and it was down 5% sequentially. Compensation-related expense dropped 2% compared to last year. And the compensation ratio in Q3 was 15.2%, down slightly from a year ago. Our noncompensation-related expenses were down less than 1% compared to the third quarter of last year. 
Looking at the nonoperating income and expense line. Our ownership in the S&P Dow Jones joint venture drove $28.4 million in net earnings from unconsolidated subsidiaries, which was the highest level we have ever achieved.
Turning to investment income. We received $2.7 million in dividends from BM&FBOVESPA. In addition, our investment returns, generated through the reinvestment of cash performance bonds and guaranteed fund contributions, increased sequentially to $7.3 million from $5.2 million in Q2. This is a result of a higher average net return compared to the prior quarter. For Q3 this year, we had an average net return of 13 basis points. 
Taxes for the quarter ended at an adjusted 36.6%, which is slightly above where we guided. 
And now to the balance sheet. At the end of the third quarter, we had almost $1.6 billion in cash, restricted cash and marketable securities, up approximately $260 million from the prior quarter. Earlier this month, we sold down our BM&FBOVESPA stake to approximately 2.4% and raised approximately $150 million. The brokerage costs were minimal, so the vast maturity of that will be included in our cash balance and available when we determine the annual variable dividend. We believe the steady return of capital has differentiated us from our peers, and we believe we are well positioned to continue to supplement our earnings growth with a healthy dividend for years to come. 
During the quarter, capital expenditures net of leasehold improvement allowances were $23 million. The level of capital expenditures is impacted as we continue to leverage more software- and infrastructure-as-a-service, which is included in expense. I now expect CapEx to come in a bit below $100 million for the year, driven by the shedding of our real estate assets and the recent sale of our data center. 
Last quarter, I mentioned the subscription program that we made available for our members. We continue to work with our membership as they weigh the benefits of taking advantage of the program. The take-up so far has been relatively small. We booked about $170,000 in Q3. And with recent conversions, we are approaching a run rate of $3 million per year of new revenue.
We recently announced our 2017 pricing schedule. In a targeted fashion, we adjusted the volume discount tiers, incentive plans and the base rates. If volume comes in exactly as it has this year, we would expect transaction fees resulting from the change to increase by 2%. We take a very long-term view on pricing changes. Our goal is to increase volumes which reduces the overall costs to trade on our markets as we bring in more participants and enhance liquidity. With record volumes and open interest and an expanding number of global participants, the value to our customers from transacting in
Our markets has never been greater. 
We remain focused on being as efficient as possible. We have been reducing the core operating costs to free up expense dollars to deploy on growth
Initiatives. We are currently working on our 2017 budget and will report out on our plans next quarter. 
Last quarter, we adjusted our expense guidance, excluding license fees, for the second half of 2016 down to $548 million. The guidance remains unchanged as we have a normal ramp in the fourth quarter for marketing events. We anticipate launching a new retail advertising campaign that will likely impact us in Q4, and we are expecting higher pro fees based on some growth-oriented projects that are underway. The guidance translates to less than 1% expense growth in 2016 on this basis. 
In summary, so far this year, revenue is up $169 million, and our incremental operating margin is 94%. Without license fees, that jumps to about 100%. Our secular growth drivers continue to deliver results with or without volatility. Our efficiency on expenses has been excellent. And since the first of the year, we have returned $1.6 billion in dividends.
With that, we'd like to open up the call for your questions. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Michael Carrier with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Michael Carrier with Bank of America.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, maybe first one, just on expenses. Obviously good in the quarter, and when we look at the full year guidance, it looks like the fourth quarter -- I know there's seasonality, but there's a decent ramp, I think, even relative to maybe last year, a bit
componenttext: John, maybe first one, just on expenses. Obviously good in the quarter, and when we look at the full year guidance, it looks like the fourth quarter -- I know there's seasonality, but there's a decent ramp, I think, even relative to maybe last year, a bit higher, so just wanted to get a sense on what's kind of already in the run rate, meaning that you expect versus what would be like volume base. And I know going into '17, it's early, but when we think about what you guys have said kind of longer term in like the low single-digit expense growth, just any color that you can give on how much of that is like volume oriented. And so if revenues are strong, you'll be at the top end of the range versus the bottom. And I know it's still early, but any color there.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mike. Thank you. When you take a look at the increase in expenses from Q3 to Q4, really, it's coming in primarily into 3 categories. One is compensation, which, similar to this quarter last year, included our annual adjustments to the estimates asso
componenttext: Sure, Mike. Thank you. When you take a look at the increase in expenses from Q3 to Q4, really, it's coming in primarily into 3 categories. One is compensation, which, similar to this quarter last year, included our annual adjustments to the estimates associated with stock-based compensation, which will cause an increase quarter-over-quarter -- or I mean, sorry, quarterly sequentially, an increase in the fourth quarter. There's some timing related to professional fees related to organic growth initiatives between the third and fourth quarter. And the other line, which, similar to prior years is seasonably higher in the fourth quarter and includes costs associated with marketing and customer-facing events. So to put this into context, we anticipate only a 1% annual increase in organic expenses this year, and we decided not to adjust our guidance. When you take a look at next year, we'll update everybody in the fourth quarter's conference call. But we did say that we'd be between the low and mid single digits with the higher end of the mid-single digits being due to higher revenue achievement. So the entire team here is extremely focused on expense discipline, and we're carrying that forward into 2017.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Dan Fannon with Jefferies.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Dan Fannon with Jefferies.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, John, you kind of highlighted your commitment to the dividends. But just want to talk about M&A with, obviously, industry M&A is still happening. Can you talk about how you're thinking about maybe transactional versus kind of nontransactional rev
componenttext: I guess, John, you kind of highlighted your commitment to the dividends. But just want to talk about M&A with, obviously, industry M&A is still happening. Can you talk about how you're thinking about maybe transactional versus kind of nontransactional revenue in terms of that context? Or is it really just a focus organically for you guys going forward?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Dan, thank you. So there really is no change to our view on M&A. We look at M&A with an eye on creating long-term shareholder value, so we definitely pay attention to the marketplace and are constantly looking at opportunities. If we see something t
componenttext: Sure. Dan, thank you. So there really is no change to our view on M&A. We look at M&A with an eye on creating long-term shareholder value, so we definitely pay attention to the marketplace and are constantly looking at opportunities. If we see something that is long-term value enhancing, we'll act on it. With regard to whether or not it is transactional versus nontransactional in nature, really, we look at it more from a point of view on creating long-term shareholder value. So if something does create value, and we see that it fits in our business strategically, that's something that we'll act on.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Dan, just to add to what John said. I think given the nature of the business we have, the other exchanges, we have fixed asset classes, we have benchmarks within those asset classes. And when you put the focus on client needs, I think it's entirely approp
componenttext: Dan, just to add to what John said. I think given the nature of the business we have, the other exchanges, we have fixed asset classes, we have benchmarks within those asset classes. And when you put the focus on client needs, I think it's entirely appropriate for us to, in line with what John said, look at adjacencies that might make sense to our clients, so our lens is across the ecosystems of the asset classes that we are engaging with a view to bring more value to our client base.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Chris Allen with Buckingham.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Chris Allen with Buckingham.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask a question. I guess this is probably for Terry. There's been a bunch of headlines out of the EU with regards to a transaction tax, and there's clearly some worries in the U.S. with the potential for the Democrats to gain more control ab
componenttext: I just want to ask a question. I guess this is probably for Terry. There's been a bunch of headlines out of the EU with regards to a transaction tax, and there's clearly some worries in the U.S. with the potential for the Democrats to gain more control about transaction tax. So any kind of updated thoughts on that and what you guys are hearing maybe out of D.C. and how you're thinking about it moving forward?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. I think that this is one of those topics that I've heard forever since I've been here in the last 35, 36 years. People have said, and I've actually read a few reports that if, in fact, Secretary Clinton is to prevail in the presidency, and
componenttext: Thanks, Chris. I think that this is one of those topics that I've heard forever since I've been here in the last 35, 36 years. People have said, and I've actually read a few reports that if, in fact, Secretary Clinton is to prevail in the presidency, and they also prevail in the Senate and the House and control all 3 branches of the government that it would be easier to pass a transaction tax. Well, I would say, what happened in 2008 when that was the scenario when President Barack Obama became elected and the Senate and the House both went Democrat, they didn't do anything. We work very hard on working both sides of the aisle to educate people about how they'd be putting a very, very large tax on a very small universe of people that provide liquidity for farmers to transfer risk, people to do mortgage hedging, people to do all different hedging, all the asset classes that Mr. Gill just referenced. And if those spreads widen, I've testified many times how you put forward the transaction tax of a couple hundred million dollars, let me show you how it cost the consumer several billion dollars by doing so. So I think as long as we act professional and continue to make the arguments, I'm confident that we won't see such a nonsensical tax. But at the same time, taxes are going to probably continue to go up in some way, shape or form. I don't see it in the size of a transaction tax. You have to remember that, around the rest of the world, there are transaction taxes but not on pure futures. And the ones that do have it are so de minimis, they're losing business. So most of the transaction taxes are in securities-based products, which people hold for a period of a lot longer, and they have a much larger universe of participants. When you look at our participants, and whatever the number is, I guarantee you, as we get to the bigger participants, that number is much, much smaller. So you would have a huge onus on a very small group of people, as I said earlier, and I just can't see even how our government would look at that. And that's one of the arguments that we have made historically, and I think it resonates -- listen, we've got to feed 9 billion people by 2050 with the same amount of acreage we have today. And if in fact, the cost of food goes up significantly because people can't manage risk, that's going to be a bad thing for the American people, and I think even the Democratic side of the aisle understands that.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Rich Repetto with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Rich Repetto with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just -- one comment. Well, I still don't understand the expense increase from 3Q to 4Q, John. I mean, this isn't just a little ramp. This is almost double. If you look at the last 3 year average from 3Q to 4Q, it's $18 million. You're guiding to a $3
componenttext: So I just -- one comment. Well, I still don't understand the expense increase from 3Q to 4Q, John. I mean, this isn't just a little ramp. This is almost double. If you look at the last 3 year average from 3Q to 4Q, it's $18 million. You're guiding to a $34 million increase here this year. What makes this year different than the last 3?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's -- I mean, first off, the increase from -- when you take out license fees, the increase from Q4 last year to Q4 this year is a $10 million increase. We did have timing related, some growth-oriented projects that shifted between Q3 and Q4. We al
componenttext: Well, it's -- I mean, first off, the increase from -- when you take out license fees, the increase from Q4 last year to Q4 this year is a $10 million increase. We did have timing related, some growth-oriented projects that shifted between Q3 and Q4. We also -- as I mentioned in the prepared remarks, we've got an advertising program that we're expecting to launch in the fourth quarter, so that's impacting as well. So as you've seen from what Gill had mentioned, we've got an unprecedented number of new product launches, and that's, in part -- doing that requires some organic spend. So in total, we decided not to adjust our guidance. And as I mentioned, it's really a 1% annual increase in expenses. And in fact, if you look at the last 2 quarters of 2014 and compare that to the last 2 quarters of 2016, we're flat.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe for Kim. Wanted to see where CME was in the process of setting up the account with the Fed for the investment of nonhouse cash. I think a few months ago, you thought it might be completed by now. So where does it stand? And if it is completed or wer
componenttext: Maybe for Kim. Wanted to see where CME was in the process of setting up the account with the Fed for the investment of nonhouse cash. I think a few months ago, you thought it might be completed by now. So where does it stand? And if it is completed or were completed, at this point in time, how much nonhouse cash could be deposited if the account were, in fact, open?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- I think we've been talking more about house cash, and I think that total -- the total house cash that we hold is kind of on the order of $20 billion. It fluctuates from day to day. We have our accounts open for the house cash with the Fed, and we'r
componenttext: The -- I think we've been talking more about house cash, and I think that total -- the total house cash that we hold is kind of on the order of $20 billion. It fluctuates from day to day. We have our accounts open for the house cash with the Fed, and we're going through the kind of the last stages of the testing to make sure that everything will flow appropriately. And then we're still working with the CFTC and the Fed on the nonhouse cash of what we would call the customer cash as well.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any time line on the noncustomer -- nonhouse cash side?
componenttext: Any time line on the noncustomer -- nonhouse cash side?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the customer cash side, the nonhouse, that is -- that timing is really in the hands of the Federal Reserve, and it's not something that is very easy to handicap.
componenttext: On the customer cash side, the nonhouse, that is -- that timing is really in the hands of the Federal Reserve, and it's not something that is very easy to handicap.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Alex Kramm with UBS.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Alex Kramm with UBS.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Probably for Gill but maybe for some of the others, too. You mentioned, Gill, the uncleared margin rules that came in, in September. Can you elaborate a little bit in terms of the discussions and what you've seen from clients in terms of -- I hear you on
componenttext: Probably for Gill but maybe for some of the others, too. You mentioned, Gill, the uncleared margin rules that came in, in September. Can you elaborate a little bit in terms of the discussions and what you've seen from clients in terms of -- I hear you on NDFs, but I think, historically, you've also talked about maybe uncleared margin rules would drive more uptick in futures. And then just lastly, who's shifting so far? What kind of customers? Because I think the bigger group of clients coming on in March, so just curious if you think that's going to be a bigger bump and more dramatic change when those rules come in.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Alex. This is Sean jumping in. On the uncleared margin rules, September 1 was the date U.S., Japan and Canada implemented them. The CFTC had no-action relief until October 3. The biggest impact, according to the BIS reports, are in rates and foreign
componenttext: Sure, Alex. This is Sean jumping in. On the uncleared margin rules, September 1 was the date U.S., Japan and Canada implemented them. The CFTC had no-action relief until October 3. The biggest impact, according to the BIS reports, are in rates and foreign exchange. In terms of rates, the biggest new offering that we have out there that we think could help relieve some of the challenges that the market faces are swaptions clearing. On swaptions clearings, we currently have 7 clearing members who have been approved by the Risk Committee, 2 new clearing members in the last couple of months. And we're excited that that's a great place to relieve a lot of the uncleared margin requirements in the rates area. Then if you look at the FX market, as you said, the NDF market, we have an NDF mark offering out here. We also clear cash settle forwards. But in addition to that, we've began working very hard on OTC FX options clearing. And we believe the combination of all those products together will be very attractive to market participants. We're working very closely with a set of market participants on that. In terms of equities, equities, according to BIS reports, kind of third after those other tranche of [ph] classes in terms of the impacts on the marketplace. We launched on our August, late August, a total return S&P 500 futures that would nearly replicate the economics of a total return swap, so the OTC equity swaps market. With the no-action relief until October 3, we didn't see any trades in that until the week of October 3rd, but that week, immediately, with several participants trade in their first week, about 3,500 contracts -- so you're talking about $3.5 billion, approximately, and they traded in blocks of about $500 million each. So you have very large participants testing the pipes relative to the equity futures, the equity total return futures. In terms of the next 4 years, it's only the top 20 or 21 [ph] institutions in the world that are affected today. Over the next 4 years, the expectation is that will become over 2,000 firms, so we do expect it -- relative to our focus on it, relative to new products and services that we're offering, that will -- there'll be a lot of pain out there that we can help relieve with the new cleared products as well as the new -- as well as our futures products.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Patrick O'Shaughnessy with Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Patrick O'Shaughnessy with Raymond James.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the dealers keep bringing up the topic of the skin in the game and the clearinghouses and how much capital that CME puts up in terms of the waterfall. What are your current views in terms of maybe additional money that you'll need to put into clearing
componenttext: So the dealers keep bringing up the topic of the skin in the game and the clearinghouses and how much capital that CME puts up in terms of the waterfall. What are your current views in terms of maybe additional money that you'll need to put into clearing houses? And what sort of leverage do the dealers have to try to impact your behavior there?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure. And I'll ask Kim to join in. I'm not sure about the leverage that the dealers would actually have, but they're actually focused on the skin-in-the-game issue itself. As you may or may not know, we pioneered the concept in the late 60s, and w
componenttext: I'm not sure. And I'll ask Kim to join in. I'm not sure about the leverage that the dealers would actually have, but they're actually focused on the skin-in-the-game issue itself. As you may or may not know, we pioneered the concept in the late 60s, and we're comfortable with skin in the game. We think it's necessary to have. But we're also very, very much in tune with respect to the moral hazard issue here. And if you look at our skin in the game and what the amount is, there are tons of views out there, all the ad hoc views with respect to what that amount should actually be. From our perspective, at the $500 million or so level that we have across the board, it's about the average contribution of each of those firms, all right. And we have affirmatively said that we strongly believe that those that bring risk should be the ones that fund the guarantee fund. We manage the risk that they bring, and we are ultra comfortable with the levels that we have. Anything to add, Kim?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just expand a little bit on the moral hazard point. I mean, I agree with Gill that we are very big believers in skin in the game from the clearing house. The clearing house needs the alignment of incentives with the clearing member. But the cleari
componenttext: I would just expand a little bit on the moral hazard point. I mean, I agree with Gill that we are very big believers in skin in the game from the clearing house. The clearing house needs the alignment of incentives with the clearing member. But the clearing members are very important participants in any kind of default management situation. And the mutualization of risk across clearing mechanisms is part of the reason why clearing-house mechanism works so effectively. And turning too much of that to the contribution of the CCP upfront could change the dynamics of the risk mechanisms that support a good default management. So the moral hazard is very real and shows up in multiple ways in the process.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just thinking through the dividend policy and I guess the tradeoff between increase in fee variable -- the increase in your occurring dividend versus a bigger special as we're thinking out over the next year or so. Just curious to get your update on th
componenttext: So just thinking through the dividend policy and I guess the tradeoff between increase in fee variable -- the increase in your occurring dividend versus a bigger special as we're thinking out over the next year or so. Just curious to get your update on that.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We feel very strongly that we've got a very good dividend policy between the regular dividend and the annual variable dividend. As you saw this year, we adjusted our regular dividend up 20% to create more of a balance between the annual variable and the r
componenttext: We feel very strongly that we've got a very good dividend policy between the regular dividend and the annual variable dividend. As you saw this year, we adjusted our regular dividend up 20% to create more of a balance between the annual variable and the regular dividend. So we are very committed to the policy. And as we mentioned in the prepared remarks, there'll be some positive increases in terms of the amount of cash going into the fourth quarter related to our sale down of our stake in BM&F. So that freed up about $150 million in cash that can be used when determining the annual variable dividend.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I was just thinking that, is the increase in the quarterly something we should expect every year from you guys, or was the event this year kind of one time?
componenttext: Sure. I was just thinking that, is the increase in the quarterly something we should expect every year from you guys, or was the event this year kind of one time?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really -- it's a board decision, but if you take a look at our past, we've had a policy of consistently increasing our regular dividend. But it's really a board decision, and it's something that we'll be analyzing in the fourth quarter along with the
componenttext: It's really -- it's a board decision, but if you take a look at our past, we've had a policy of consistently increasing our regular dividend. But it's really a board decision, and it's something that we'll be analyzing in the fourth quarter along with the annual variable dividend level.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Kyle Voigt with KBW.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Kyle Voigt with KBW.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the energy slide comparing your WTI versus ICE's Brent contract. I think if we look at futures open interest specifically, we aren't seeing necessarily the same shift. So can you help us understand the variance there between open interest and ADV?
componenttext: Just on the energy slide comparing your WTI versus ICE's Brent contract. I think if we look at futures open interest specifically, we aren't seeing necessarily the same shift. So can you help us understand the variance there between open interest and ADV? And I guess what is driving the increased volume and activity rates in your WTI contract?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Kyle, it's Derek. Thanks for your question. We're actually very excited about the growth rates that we've been able to unlock in our energy complex. And it's a number of factors both -- that we are controlling for in terms of our ability to both roll
componenttext: Yes. Kyle, it's Derek. Thanks for your question. We're actually very excited about the growth rates that we've been able to unlock in our energy complex. And it's a number of factors both -- that we are controlling for in terms of our ability to both roll out product, acquire new customers, position our benchmark product in what is a market that is shifting structurally in favor of our benchmark products that whether you look at the -- lifting the export ban in crude back in December of 2015, creating a water balloon product that is WTI, we now have a product that the market is increasingly adopting as a global benchmark. As Gill referenced in his earlier comments at the top of the call, our growth in Asia, particularly in our energies franchise, is up in excess of 100%. So adoption and participation in our markets globally is increasing as we're leveraging. Bryan's team's on the ground in Europe and in Asia to go access and bring new customers on board. And we actually think about the energies complex as a whole. We're thinking about well beyond just the crude story. We're talking about nat gas as well. So as we talk about the overall franchise on Slide 9 of the deck that we sent you guys, in the same structural shifts we talk about that are beneficial to our crude business favoring WTI over Brent, we're also seeing some reconnecting of the global nat gas market. On Slide 9, on the right-hand side, we've got a graph of what we're showing as a reconnecting of the prices of U.S. nat gas, really driven by our physical Henry Hub products between the prices both in Asia and Germany. And you look at the market share that we've grown to, we are now 76% market share of the global Henry Hub futures market, and that's up from 73% in 2015 and 68% in 2014. So we're excited about, as markets converge, the role that the Henry Hub futures complex, the physical part that we launch will play as a benchmark product pricing in the global nat gas market as those prices disconnect from the crude market and reconnect globally. Also, the open interest levels, over the course of this year, we've reached not only record levels for open interest in nat gas, but we're hovering right at all-time highs [ph] in our large open interest holders on the futures side. And on the options, as we talked about previously, record levels of electronification and nat gas options and continued growth. Our nat gas options business at over 30% this year.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just staying on the energy theme. Can you comment, Derek, about your NASDAQ NFX effort, whether that's actually enhancing your volumes given the arbitrage between markets. And if that program is expanded over time, is that a net benefit for you? Or do you
componenttext: Just staying on the energy theme. Can you comment, Derek, about your NASDAQ NFX effort, whether that's actually enhancing your volumes given the arbitrage between markets. And if that program is expanded over time, is that a net benefit for you? Or do you see that actually eventually being sort of a headwind on the incumbent's market shares?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we look at the progress that we've made relative to the business that we developed, we've got a nice problem. We've got a market that's up over 30% in September volume-wise, as I mentioned, the market share increasing like 70% on the futures side. Ou
componenttext: When we look at the progress that we've made relative to the business that we developed, we've got a nice problem. We've got a market that's up over 30% in September volume-wise, as I mentioned, the market share increasing like 70% on the futures side. Our market share relative of the nat gas options is still around 64% or 65%. But what we've really done is we've focused on electronifying the nat gas options business. So when you look at what the other offerings are out there, this is a market that's typically been brokered, and we're the ones that have gone from less than 10% of electronic in nat gas options to a record of over 40%, as Gill mentioned at the top of the call. And as you've seen us do across products over time, when you focus on functionality in electronic access to your options market, bringing people to the transparent central order [ph] book, we tend to see the velocity of transactions increase, and more important, we can access a global customer base. That's really hard to do in a block market. So we're excited about the progress we've made, the large open interest holder record levels that we're touching on is really a reflection of the increased global adoption of our product set, so we're excited about the multiple records we've hit in nat gas options, ADV, single-day record, large open interest holders, as well as the deferred month liquidity that we have built and focused on over the last 12 months as well. Our open interest in months 6 through 12 is up 36% as we're focusing on the commercial end-user customers to bring them into our market, and those are the physical users that are using our product.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just add to that, particularly out of Asia, which has been a bit of a struggle in the past in terms of the adoption of our energy products. The leader in terms of growth throughout Greater China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, as well as within Korea is unque
componenttext: I would just add to that, particularly out of Asia, which has been a bit of a struggle in the past in terms of the adoption of our energy products. The leader in terms of growth throughout Greater China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, as well as within Korea is unquestionably been in the energy. Those that had traditionally favored the alternative to our WTI have been increasingly adopting our crude. And they've been very noticeably active in the natural gas and very pleased to see the greater transparency associated with that. So we're going to continue driving that progress within those regions. Same holds true for within greater Europe.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Vincent Hung with Autonomous.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Vincent Hung with Autonomous.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to get your take on the FSB paper on CCP and what global regulators are doing in respect to the systemic risk of CCP. So where do you expect regulation to go, if anywhere at all?
componenttext: I just wanted to get your take on the FSB paper on CCP and what global regulators are doing in respect to the systemic risk of CCP. So where do you expect regulation to go, if anywhere at all?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vincent, this is Gill. I'll answer, then I'll ask Kim to add if she has anything to add. I think the FSB, like all the other regulators, are concerned about CCP resiliency, just as Chairman Massad of the CFTC is. And I think the authorities such as the CF
componenttext: Vincent, this is Gill. I'll answer, then I'll ask Kim to add if she has anything to add. I think the FSB, like all the other regulators, are concerned about CCP resiliency, just as Chairman Massad of the CFTC is. And I think the authorities such as the CFTC are familiar with CCP, is familiar with the risk that CCPs bring, and they're comfortable, I think, with the framework that they have been overseeing for decades. I think the FSB, which includes some of the central banks of the world that don't necessarily -- have not necessarily overseen CCPs are coming to grips to what those means, and they're looking at various and sundry scenarios, and this is all part and parcel of the knock-on effects of the crisis of 2008. On our part, we're working very hard to educate to the extent that we can and also contribute to the debate to the extent that we are allowed to.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would just add a couple of things. Gill mentioned the kind of varying perspectives of different regulators. And one of the things -- a part of our advocacy is to help educate regulators that are newer to the regulation of clearing houses or CCPs. B
componenttext: Yes. I would just add a couple of things. Gill mentioned the kind of varying perspectives of different regulators. And one of the things -- a part of our advocacy is to help educate regulators that are newer to the regulation of clearing houses or CCPs. Because although the G20 and the regulation have pushed products into clearing mechanisms because clearing mechanisms worked in the crisis, the interesting thing is it now they are thinking about slightly changing the way clearing mechanisms need to work, so we want to make sure that clearing mechanisms maintain their effectiveness, and our advocacy is in that regard with respect to flexibility and crisis management and the ability to have strong risk-management programs.

componenttext: Sure. This is John. I'll take it, and I'll ask Derek to comment specifically on the energy side. So within equities, we had a higher proportion of member trading. And in energy, we had 2 factors. One is we had a larger proportion of member trading than last quarter with member volumes up 19% and nonmembers up 15%. We also saw a large increase in the use of our electronic natural gas options, which are lower price than ClearPort. And Derek, you want to comment on what you're seeing in terms of options trading, that would be great. But before we do that, I'll just mention in terms of the advertising campaign, yes, it's geared towards more retail and nonmembers. So with that, I'll hand it over to Derek on the options.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the nat gas side, as John mentioned, there's 2 things going on. Number one, you've seen us build into sustainable growth in options markets by making sure that we can build those markets electronically, so we can market that liquidity globally. We
componenttext: Yes. On the nat gas side, as John mentioned, there's 2 things going on. Number one, you've seen us build into sustainable growth in options markets by making sure that we can build those markets electronically, so we can market that liquidity globally. We faced the market structure in nat gas options a year ago that was 95% brokered, less than 5% traded on screen. So every time we shifted businesses from a brokered market on to the screen, we've done that because our experience has shown that you create a sticky ecosystem of user participants by bringing them into the central limit order book. The downside of that is you end up giving up our block surcharge when we charge people an excess amount for dealing outside of the central limit order book. So it's been a very disciplined approach to move that business on screen, so we're finding that great deal of success, moving from less than 10% electronic to a record of 44% electronic earlier this year, I think in August and September, so it's a shift that we have anticipated, a shift we've undertaken in other markets as we globalize and electronify them and with the business up 31%, typically, you also start to move through volume tiers as well. So we consider this a first world problem relative to volumes growth and a disciplined move on to a central limit order book.
