componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Vincent Hung with Autonomous.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to get your take on the FSB paper on CCP and what global regulators are doing in respect to the systemic risk of CCP. So where do you expect regulation to go, if anywhere at all?
componenttext: I just wanted to get your take on the FSB paper on CCP and what global regulators are doing in respect to the systemic risk of CCP. So where do you expect regulation to go, if anywhere at all?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Vincent, this is Gill. I'll answer, then I'll ask Kim to add if she has anything to add. I think the FSB, like all the other regulators, are concerned about CCP resiliency, just as Chairman Massad of the CFTC is. And I think the authorities such as the CF
componenttext: Vincent, this is Gill. I'll answer, then I'll ask Kim to add if she has anything to add. I think the FSB, like all the other regulators, are concerned about CCP resiliency, just as Chairman Massad of the CFTC is. And I think the authorities such as the CFTC are familiar with CCPs, is familiar with the risk that CCPs bring, and they're comfortable, I think, with the framework that they have been overseeing for decades. I think the FSB, which includes some of the central banks of the world that don't necessarily -- have not necessarily overseen CCPs are coming to grips to what those means, and they're looking at various and sundry scenarios, and this is all part and parcel of the knock-on effects of the crisis of 2008. On our part, we're working very hard to educate to the extent that we can and also contribute to the debate to the extent that we are allowed to.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would just add a couple of things. Gill mentioned the kind of varying perspectives of different regulators. And one of the things -- part of our advocacy is to help educate regulators that are newer to the regulation of clearinghouses or CCPs. Beca
componenttext: Yes. I would just add a couple of things. Gill mentioned the kind of varying perspectives of different regulators. And one of the things -- part of our advocacy is to help educate regulators that are newer to the regulation of clearinghouses or CCPs. Because although the G20 and the regulation have pushed products into clearing mechanisms because clearing mechanisms worked in the crisis, the interesting thing is it now they are thinking about slightly changing the way clearing mechanisms need to work, so we want to make sure that clearing mechanisms maintain their effectiveness, and our advocacy is in that regard with respect to flexibility and crisis management and the ability to have strong risk-management programs.

Or are you seeing end customers take actions to try to reduce their RPCs? And in addition, the advertising you mentioned in the fourth quarter, is that geared towards trying to drive more nonmember activity?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This is John. I'll take it, and I'll ask Derek to comment specifically on the energy side. So within equities, we had a higher proportion of member trading. And in energy, we had 2 factors: One, is we had a larger proportion of member trading than l
componenttext: Sure. This is John. I'll take it, and I'll ask Derek to comment specifically on the energy side. So within equities, we had a higher proportion of member trading. And in energy, we had 2 factors: One, is we had a larger proportion of member trading than last quarter with member volumes up 19% and nonmembers up 15%. We also saw a large increase in the use of our electronic natural gas options which are lower price than ClearPort. And Derek, you want to comment on what you're seeing in terms of options trading, that would be great. But before you do that, I'll just mention in terms of the advertising campaign, yes, it's geared towards more retail and nonmembers. So with that, I'll hand it over to Derek on the options.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On the nat gas side, as John mentioned, there's 2 things going on. Number one, you've seen us build into sustainable growth in options markets by making sure that we can build those markets electronically, so we can market that liquidity globally. We
componenttext:
Yes. On the nat gas side, as John mentioned, there's 2 things going on. Number one, you've seen us build into sustainable growth in options markets by making sure that we can build those markets electronically, so we can market that liquidity globally. We faced the market structure in nat gas options a year ago that was 95% brokered, less than 5% traded on screen. So every time we shifted businesses from a brokered market onto the screen, we've done that because our experience has shown that you create a sticky ecosystem of user participants by bringing them into the central limit order book. The downside of that is you end up giving up our block surcharge when we charge people an excess amount for dealing outside of the central limit order book. 
So it's been a very disciplined approach to move that business on screen, so we're finding that great deal of success, moving from less than 10% electronic to a record of 44% electronic earlier this year, I think in August and September. So it's a shift that we have anticipated, a shift we've undertaken in other markets as we globalize and electronify them, and with the business up 31%, typically, you also start to move through volume tiers as well. So we consider this a first world problem relative to volumes growth and a disciplined move on to a central limit order book.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a couple follow-ups. I'll start on market data. I don't think you've mentioned it, but I think you've given some guidance in the past there. It was down sequentially. Any updated views of how that should be trending in the next quarter or maybe ev
componenttext: I guess a couple follow-ups. I'll start on market data. I don't think you've mentioned it, but I think you've given some guidance in the past there. It was down sequentially. Any updated views of how that should be trending in the next quarter or maybe even in 2017, as you -- as people trade in their memberships and things like that -- or their screens, rather?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Bryan. First of all, just to give you a little color, since the elimination of the electronic fee waiver's been in full effect now for almost a year, where in all of our professional users are paying the full market data subscriber fee revenues and o
componenttext:
It's Bryan. First of all, just to give you a little color, since the elimination of the electronic fee waiver's been in full effect now for almost a year, where in all of our professional users are paying the full market data subscriber fee revenues and our subscribers remain stable. Now as we continued to advance our market data and IP growth opportunities, we've been performing a holistic assessment of our current program. And our assessment indicates that there are opportunities to extract additional value in revenues from our assets. So for example in 2017, we expect that the manner in which we charge for our core market data services will be modified to tailor our fees in a more targeted fashion. Our approach to charging trading and nontrading participants will be modified to address the global nature of this business and the various subscriber profiles that are consuming our data. So we believe our current pricing scheme does not fully capture the value Alex described to these different user segments. 
And just to give you a recent example of our targeted approach, I think I referenced at the last call that we are increasingly commercializing our derived and historical market data offerings. So with respect to derived data, there are increasing opportunities, and there is a significant pipeline of demand per our data IP as the demand for the development of external product continues to increase. Now this clearly has been an area of revenue opportunity for us that we plan to drive greater growth, and it's been typically referenced in the past as core market data. So we will be separating that out increasingly and going after those opportunities on a derived basis. I think you also may be aware of our recent announcement of our new historical market data platform which we just recently introduced in conjunction with TickSmith. The usable data needs to be instantly accessible, and we've done that with our recent introduction of TickVault. Data users now can browse a data catalog, subscribe to the content needed and access it via the web interfaces and APIs almost instantaneously. 
So this is making data access easily -- easy, and it's responsive to the global demand that we've been hearing, so we see more opportunities to extract more value in that regard. So that just gives you a taste of how we're relooking at the assets from the market data and IP perspective.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, Alex, just one more point on that. When I look at the fourth quarter, I think market data will be in the neighborhood of $100 million.
componenttext: I'm sorry, Alex, just one more point on that. When I look at the fourth quarter, I think market data will be in the neighborhood of $100 million.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, great. That was more color than I expected. I guess just moving on, just one follow-up more here. On the new membership opportunity, I think you said it's a little bit disappointing relative to what you expected. So can you just talk about like
componenttext: All right, great. That was more color than I expected. I guess just moving on, just one follow-up more here. On the new membership opportunity, I think you said it's a little bit disappointing relative to what you expected. So can you just talk about like the feedback you've gotten? Is it basically people saying your stock is a good value, we like the dividend, we'll keep it? Or any other reasons why maybe the take-up has not been as high as you expected?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I wouldn't say it wasn't as high as we expected. I think we're right now at about a $3 million run rate per year in terms of the amount that we gave out in terms of take-up. So although it's only 170,000 for the quarter, we're at a $3 million run ra
componenttext: Sure. I wouldn't say it wasn't as high as we expected. I think we're right now at about a $3 million run rate per year in terms of the amount that we gave out in terms of take-up. So although it's only 170,000 for the quarter, we're at a $3 million run rate. So it does take time for firms to make these decisions. As you indicated, they're weighing the annual variable dividend they get in the fourth quarter by -- or into the first quarter as for holding our shares, so they take a look at that. Also, we think it's beneficial for new members coming in, especially those from overseas, that we're holding CME stock, and having that amount of capital is prohibitive. So that takes time to work through the system. So in terms of the overall opportunity being about $40 million, we're at roughly 10% of that, and it's only been out for just a couple of months. So for us -- this is really nothing but upside for us.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one last one. Apologies in advance, but you mentioned the retail advertising. Any particular reason why you're so focused on retail right now? I mean, can you just remind us how big retail is for you? Is this a global campaign? Is this just
componenttext: Okay. And just one last one. Apologies in advance, but you mentioned the retail advertising. Any particular reason why you're so focused on retail right now? I mean, can you just remind us how big retail is for you? Is this a global campaign? Is this just a U.S. campaign? And why now? Why you think there's an opportunity in retail?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Definitely, a global campaign. And we've been working towards this for the past several years, cultivating opportunity and growth from this retail segment. And to give more focus on it, this past year, we actually separated it out as a distinct client seg
componenttext: Definitely, a global campaign. And we've been working towards this for the past several years, cultivating opportunity and growth from this retail segment. And to give more focus on it, this past year, we actually separated it out as a distinct client segment line headed up by a gentleman that's been leading it for a number of years on our behalf, Mark Omens. Now as we see the growth happening across our asset classes, it's representing a very significant revenue stream for us, looking at it from the nonmember perspective as well. And we see that across all of our asset classes. It's one of the fastest-growing segments that we've seen. Terry?

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I agree with that. I think that when you look at our revenue coming out of our traditional retail, the way we measured it, basically next to nothing and then putting in roughly a couple hundred million dollars, I think, last year alone in coming
componenttext: Yes. No, I agree with that. I think that when you look at our revenue coming out of our traditional retail, the way we measured it, basically next to nothing and then putting in roughly a couple hundred million dollars, I think, last year alone in coming from the retail side of the business, the upside is just extraordinary. We have, I think, somewhere in the neighborhood of 4% of the retail trade globally. And that if we could just double that, you can imagine what the revenue could do for this company. So we are taking a strong look at that. I think what's important is, here, we're not targeting the mom and pops on the street. When we call retail, we're talking about participants that are in the market today trading anywhere from 10 to 20 contracts a day already, and we're trying to harness that into the business. What I think is also fascinating is when you look at some of these discount retail equity brokers traditionally, they're starting to merge together the ones that offer futures. So that only bodes well for us to concentrate this more among people that are already offering these products.

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

headline: CME Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. And for some closing remarks, the entire team at CME is focused on maximizing our secular drivers and taking advantage of the structural changes in our markets. We're operating the business as efficiently as possible. Let me illustrat
componenttext: Thank you very much. And for some closing remarks, the entire team at CME is focused on maximizing our secular drivers and taking advantage of the structural changes in our markets. We're operating the business as efficiently as possible. Let me illustrate that for you. When you compare the first 3 quarters of 2014 with the first 3 quarters of 2016, we've grown the top line over $400 million and our adjusted expenses are down $23 million while continuing to innovate and launch many successful new products. So thank you very much for joining us today, and we look forward to speaking with you next quarter. Thank you.
